meanings.definition: the process of limiting the harmful effects of an action or a mistake:

Management launched a damage limitation exercise after details of talks with unions were leaked to the press.

meanings.definition: harmed or spoiled:
examples: They're selling off damaged goods at reduced prices.
Both the cars involved in the accident looked badly damaged.

meanings.definition: money that is paid to someone by a person or organization who was responsible for causing some injury or loss:
examples: They were awarded $500,000 in damages.

meanings.definition: causing harm:
examples: Many chemicals have a damaging effect on the environment.
These allegations are very damaging.

meanings.definition: in a way that causes harm:
examples: Most damagingly for workers, their living standards are falling because prices are rising more quickly than wages.
Ready-to-eat sandwiches sometimes contain damagingly high levels of salt.

meanings.definition: the capital city of Syria, in the southwestern part of the country:
examples: Our senior international correspondent is reporting live from Damascus.
The finest sight in Damascus is, of course, the Ummayad Mosque.

meanings.definition: a type of heavy cloth that has a pattern woven into it that is the same colour as the cloth:
examples: a white damask tablecloth

meanings.definition: a type of rose (= garden plant with large, pleasant-smelling flowers and thorns (= sharp points) on its stems) with pink or red flowers:
examples: He planted a double pink damask rose with a heady fragrance that bloomed throughout the summer and autumn.
The garden was planted with bright hollyhocks and damask roses.

meanings.definition: a flower from the damask rose plant, used to make perfume (= liquid with a pleasant smell, often used on the skin):
examples: Rose water is made using damask roses.
Garlands of pink damask roses are intertwined with pale blue forget-me-nots.

meanings.definition: a woman
the funny character of an older woman, usually played by a man, in a pantomime (= a musical play for children)
a title used in front of a woman's name that is given in Britain as a special honour, usually for valuable work done over a long period, or a woman having this honour:
examples: Dame Judy Dench

meanings.definition: a woman:
examples: a fast-talking dame

meanings.definition: the rank of Dame (= a title used in front of a woman's name that is given in Britain as a special honour, usually for valuable work done over a long period):
examples: She was given a damehood after winning two gold medals at the Olympics.
Despite being awarded a damehood in the 2023 honours list, she is little known outside academic circles.
Among those raised to damehood was the singer Shirley Bassey.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         dam

present participle of 
        
         dam
an expression of anger :
examples: He banged his fist on the desk angrily. "Dammit!"
Just let me speak, damnit!

meanings.definition: used for emphasis:
examples: But dammit, I don't care.
Damnit I'm glad to be here.

meanings.definition: an expression of anger:
examples: Damn, I've spilled coffee down my blouse!
It's broken! Damn!

meanings.definition: used for emphasis:
examples: Damn, that tastes good.
I don't brag very often, but damn, I'm going to brag about this!

meanings.definition: used, especially when you are annoyed, to mean "very":
examples: He knew damn well how much trouble it would cause.
Next time he can damn well do it himself!
You were damn lucky not to have been killed!

meanings.definition: used for describing something when you are annoyed about it:
examples: Where did I put the damn keys?
The damn thing is broken again.

meanings.definition: used for describing something when you want to emphasize it:
examples: That's a damn shame.
It's a damn sight easier if you know what you're doing.

meanings.definition: to blame or strongly criticize something or someone:
examples: The inquiry into the disaster damns the company for its lack of safety precautions.

meanings.definition: (especially of God) to force someone to stay in hell and be punished for ever:
examples: As a child she was taught that she would be damned for her sins.

meanings.definition: used to express anger with someone or something:
examples: "Stop that, you damn fool!" he shouted.

meanings.definition: an expression of anger or annoyance:
examples: Damn! I spilled coffee on my blouse.

meanings.definition: used to express surprise:
examples: Damn, I guess they decided to buy that house.

meanings.definition: used to express anger or annoyance:
examples: a damn shame

meanings.definition: very; great:
examples: You’re a damn fool to try and drive that old car cross-country.

meanings.definition: to blame or strongly criticize:
examples: The novel was damned by the critics for being too political.

meanings.definition: to force someone to stay in hell and be punished forever
the least amount:
examples: This old car isn’t worth a damn.

meanings.definition: nothing:
examples: I know damn all about computers.
It's a terrible situation and the worst thing is that you can do damn all about it.
These kids do damn all in the way of physical activity.
I had damn all in the way of experience.
I was being asked to speak about a subject that I knew damn all about.
I know what Ethan's promises are worth - damn all!

meanings.definition: to blame or strongly criticize something or someone for something:
examples: The inquiry into the disaster damns the company for its lack of safety precautions.
There were several newspaper reports the following day damning him for his arrogance.

meanings.definition: used to say that you do not care about something:
examples: I'm going to say what I think, and damn the consequences.
Their attitude seems to be "Damn the environment. We're going to drill."
I'm going to get tickets and damn the expense!
I'm buying the more expensive coat. Damn the cost.
I'm going to do what I want and damn the rest of them.
For so long we've acted like we're going to take what we want from the earth and damn the future.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize something you are saying, especially when you are angry or annoyed:
examples: He knew damn well how much trouble it would cause.
Next time you can damn well do it yourself!

meanings.definition: to praise someone or something so little or with so little enthusiasm that it suggests you do not really admire them:
examples: Of course, to say a restaurant isn't as bad as you thought it would be is to damn with faint praise.
Some critics, while respecting his previous work, will damn his new ideas with faint praise.
He appeared in his interview to damn his colleague with faint praise.

meanings.definition: used to express anger with someone or something:
examples: You got the last ticket - damn you, I wanted that!
They've refused our request - damn them!
They won't accept bookings for parties of fewer than five, it says here. Damn them, we'll go somewhere else!
It looks like he's not going to come, damn him!
There's nothing that woman can't do - damn her!
The stupid car wouldn't start this morning, damn it!

meanings.definition: very annoying:
examples: This damnable car! It just won't start on cold mornings!

meanings.definition: in a way that is very annoying:
examples: The game is damnably difficult to understand.
It was so damnably hot and I felt sleepy.

meanings.definition: the act of sending someone to hell or the state of being in hell:
examples: He believed that he would be condemned to eternal damnation for what he had done.

meanings.definition: including a lot of criticism or showing clearly that someone is wrong, guilty, or has behaved very badly:
examples: A witness statement of a damnatory nature was read out in court.
a damnatory clause

meanings.definition: used to express anger with someone or something:
examples: This damned printer won't work.

meanings.definition: the people who have been sent to hell after death

damned-if-do-and-damned-if-don-t.name: damned if you do and damned if you don’t

meanings.definition: criticized whatever you decide to do:
examples: Well, this is one of these things where you’re damned if you do and damned if you don’t.

meanings.definition: very surprising or unusual:
examples: Well that's the damnedest excuse I've ever heard!

meanings.definition: very surprising or unusual:
examples: Well, that’s the damnedest thing I ever heard!

meanings.definition: the greatest or most unusual; the best:
examples: That's the damnedest I've ever seen!

meanings.definition: A damning report, judgment, remark, etc. that includes a lot of criticism or shows clearly that someone is wrong, guilty, or has behaved very badly:
examples: He made some fairly damning remarks about the government's refusal to deal with the problem.
The two men were convicted on some extremely damning evidence.

meanings.definition: very critical, or showing clearly that someone is wrong or guilty:
examples: a damning report/finding

meanings.definition: in a way that includes a lot of criticism or shows clearly that someone is wrong, guilty, or has behaved very badly:
examples: Damningly, more than 80 percent of complaints against the company were upheld.
Most damningly, the report found that prison heads failed to tackle race discrimination.

slightly wet, especially in a way that is not pleasant or comfortable:
examples: The grass is still damp.
This shirt still feels a bit damp.
It was a damp, misty morning.

meanings.definition: water in the air, in the walls of a house, etc., usually with harmful or unpleasant effects:
examples: Repointing mortar is vital to prevent damp in walls.
The damp is bad for his asthma.

meanings.definition: slightly wet, esp. in a way that is not pleasant or comfortable:
examples: damp socks
a cold, damp day

meanings.definition: a layer of material that is put in the bottom of a wall in order to stop water from rising through the bricks:
examples: We have replastered and rewired the house and put in new damp course.
If there is condensation on the underside of the glass, then your damp-proof course is probably not effective.

meanings.definition: to make a fire burn more slowly:
examples: Water was pumped from a nearby lake in an attempt to damp down the flames.

meanings.definition: to make a strong feeling be felt less strongly:
examples: He had tried to damp down speculation about the state of his marriage.

meanings.definition: an event that is not as exciting or popular as people thought it would be:
examples: After all that media attention, the whole event turned out to be a bit of a damp squib, with very few people attending.

meanings.definition: intended to stop water from getting through something and causing damage, for example in the walls of a house:
examples: On top of concrete, you will need a damp-proof membrane.
I don't think the damp-proof treatment that you carried out has had any effect.

meanings.definition: able to avoid being damaged by water getting through something:
examples: She wants to make the shed damp-proof and give it proper windows.
These paints are not damp-proof.

meanings.definition: to make changes to a building, for example to its walls, that are intended to stop water from getting through and causing damage:
examples: The thick walls are built from earth and there is no point in trying to damp-proof them.
The house had to be rewired and the basement had to be damp-proofed.

meanings.definition: actions or materials that are intended to stop water from getting through something and causing damage, for example in the walls of a house:
examples: The biggest problem in the renovation was damp-proofing.
They restored the roof and put in damp-proofing.
damp-proofing products/materials

meanings.definition: to make something slightly wet:
examples: Rain had dampened the tent so we left it to dry in the afternoon sun.

meanings.definition: to make feelings, especially of excitement or enjoyment, less strong:
examples: Nothing you can say will dampen her enthusiasm.
I didn't want to dampen his spirits.

meanings.definition: to make something slightly wet:
examples: Rain dampened the tent, but it dried in the sun.

meanings.definition: If something dampens feelings, esp. of excitement or enjoyment, it makes them less strong:
examples: I think the accident dampened his enthusiasm for baseball.

meanings.definition: to make something less strong or successful:
examples: The outlook for the global economy looked gloomy, and dampened expectations of a rise in profits that quarter.
Rising raw-material costs dampened profits for many manufacturers.

meanings.definition: to make someone less enthusiastic:
examples: Nothing you can say will dampen her enthusiasm.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel less happy:
examples: I didn't want to dampen his spirits.
Even the rain failed to dampen the spirits of the fans inside the stadium.

meanings.definition: in a slightly wet way, especially in a way that is not pleasant or comfortable:

meanings.definition: very good:

meanings.definition: to be brave enough to do something difficult or dangerous, or to be rude or silly enough to do something that you have no right to do:
examples: I was going to ask if his dog was better, but I didn't dare in case she had died.

meanings.definition: something you do because someone dares you to:

meanings.definition: the period between the time when the sun rises and the time it goes down, or the part of the day that is neither evening nor night:

meanings.definition: existing in fact, although not necessarily intended or legal:

meanings.definition: in the US, a corporation that is allowed to continue to exist, although it has not been officially made a corporation by law:

meanings.definition: If you look at someone or speak to someone de haut en bas, you do it in a way that shows you think you are superior to them. De haut en bas is French for "from high to low":

meanings.definition: having a right or existence as stated by law:

meanings.definition: having a right or existence as stated by law:

meanings.definition: used to say that someone is like a modern version of a person from the past. De nos jours is French for "of our days":

meanings.definition: to remove a website or a part of a website from the index (= list of contents) of a search engine so that it does not appear as a result of searches:
examples: You might want to de-index your website if it includes some outdated content that you plan to update later.

meanings.definition: to remove the link between a pension (= a regular payment made to someone who does not work any more) or other benefit from a list of prices, so that the payment no longer increases when those prices increase:
examples: There were concerns that the regulations would be used to de-index pension benefits.

meanings.definition: to stop a company's shares being traded on a stock market:
examples: The company's stock was delisted by Nasdaq because it failed to file required financial statements.
In extreme cases, CEOs might decide that the only option is to delist.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a company's shares stop being traded on a stock market:
examples: Illegal dealing in the company's shares led to its de-listing from the main market.
Last month saw the lowest monthly total of delistings in the past year.

meanings.definition: a process in the history of the Soviet Union which involved political and social changes to try to remove the beliefs and influence of former leader Joseph Stalin:
examples: During the period of de-Stalinization, Stalin Peak, the highest point in the USSR, was renamed Communism Peak.
After Stalin's death, Khrushchev's rise to power included a program of de-Stalinization, which condemned Stalin's dictatorial rule.

meanings.definition: to get rid of feelings of stress (= worry caused by difficult situations in your life or job):
examples: I began doing yoga as a way to de-stress.

in some Churches, a woman who performs particular duties but who is not a deacon

meanings.definition: If a place is dead, it is too quiet and nothing interesting happens there:

meanings.definition: If a piece of equipment is dead, it is not working:

meanings.definition: no longer living:

meanings.definition: If a piece of machinery or equipment is dead, it is no longer working:

meanings.definition: infml If you describe a place as dead, you mean there is not much activity there that interests you:
examples: I love my hometown, but as a teenager I always found it dead.

meanings.definition: complete or exact:

meanings.definition: completely or extremely:

meanings.definition: the deepest or most extreme part of something

meanings.definition: if a place is dead, nothing is happening there:
examples: Taxi drivers reported that business was slow and the airport has been dead.

meanings.definition: used to describe a machine or equipment that has stopped working:

meanings.definition: a period of silence during a radio or television broadcast that is not intended
in ball sports, an occasion when the ball is not in play and no points can be scored:
examples: The umpire called a dead ball because there was a dog on the field.

The team was dangerous from dead ball situations.

meanings.definition: a temporary increase in the value of shares after there has been a large reduction in their value:
examples: Are we witnessing a genuine recovery in the share price, or is it just a dead cat bounce?

meanings.definition: a temporary increase in share prices after there has been a large fall in their value:
examples: So is the share price improvement a dead cat bounce or the start of something better?

meanings.definition: someone who is quite certain to get or do something, or something that is quite certain to happen:
examples: With all her experience she's a dead cert for the job.
The pair appear to be dead certs to win the gold medal.

meanings.definition: someone or something that is very unlikely to be successful, especially because of a mistake or bad judgment:
examples: Thanks to the lack of market research, the project was a dead duck right from the start.

meanings.definition: a road that is closed at one end, and does not lead anywhere:
examples: a dead-end street

meanings.definition: a situation that has no hope of making progress:
examples: Negotiators have reached a dead end in their attempts to find a peaceful solution.

meanings.definition: If a road or path dead-ends, it is closed at one end, and does not lead anywhere:
examples: The road dead-ended halfway up the mountain.
He had to turn his bike around at the end of the trail as it dead-ended at a parking lot.

meanings.definition: a road or path that has no way out at one end:
examples: fig. Negotiators have reached a dead end (= have not been successful and cannot go further) in their attempts to find a peaceful solution.

meanings.definition: a situation that is unlikely to be successful or to make any progress:
examples: We had several customer leads that all turned out to be dead ends.
It's very demoralizing for her; she perceives that her career is at a dead end.
Plans to build a new toll road have reached a dead end.

meanings.definition: a competition in which two or more competitors finish at exactly the same time or with exactly the same result:
examples: The race ended in a dead heat.
The opinion polls show the three election candidates in a dead heat.
He was in a dead heat with the president in most polls leading up to the election.

meanings.definition: a race in which two or more competitors finish at exactly the same time:
examples: The two horses finished in a dead heat.
fig. Opinion pollsters call the Congressional race a dead heat, saying it is too close to call.

meanings.definition: a language that is no longer spoken by anyone as their main language:
examples: Latin is a dead language.

meanings.definition: a language that is no longer used for ordinary communication:
examples: Latin is a dead language.

meanings.definition: an injury caused by someone's knee or foot hitting the upper part of your leg and making the leg go numb (= without feeling):
examples: The player limped off after suffering a dead leg.

meanings.definition: a letter that cannot be delivered to the address written on it and cannot be returned to the person who sent it:
examples: the dead-letter office

meanings.definition: a law or agreement that is no longer effective:
examples: The ceasefire treaty was a dead letter as soon as it was signed, as neither side ever had any intention of keeping to it.

an activity or process that is not at all effective or successful:
examples: Yesterday's meeting was a dead loss - nothing was decided.

meanings.definition: a person who is not successful or useful:
examples: I was a dead loss at languages at school.
John was a dead loss - he just stood there and did nothing.

meanings.definition: someone who will certainly lose their job, position, title, etc. very soon:
examples: The Prime Minister is a dead man walking.
He survived the scandal but was widely considered a dead man walking going into the election.
The team were dead men walking when they came onto the pitch.
The documentary focuses on a prison chaplain who dealt with 95 "dead men walking".

meanings.definition: People who are dead cannot tell secrets:
examples: I think they killed him because he knew too much. Dead men tell no tales.

meanings.definition: a name that a transgender person (= a person whose gender does not match the body they were born with) or non-binary person (= a person who has a gender that is not male or female) was called by that they no longer use because it matched the gender they were said to have at birth:
examples: Many transgender people find their deadnames emotionally triggering and painful to hear.
Among trans and queer people, names you no longer use are often called "dead names" or "birth names".

meanings.definition: a plant with small white or coloured flowers, and leaves that look like nettles but do not sting (= cause a painful reaction when touched). Some kinds are grown in gardens, but others are considered weeds (= plants that grow where they are not wanted):
examples: Yellow deadnettle is an enchanting hedgerow plant, most noticeable in early spring.
Dead nettles grow to about 60 centimetres in height, and have pretty white flowers.

meanings.definition: the middle of the night, when it is very dark:
examples: I lay in my tent in the dead of night, listening to the noises in the woods.

meanings.definition: the middle of winter, when it is very cold:
examples: It was the dead of winter and the ground was covered in deep snow.

meanings.definition: already dead at the time of arriving at a place, especially a hospital:
examples: The motorcyclist was dead on arrival at the hospital.
She was taken to hospital where she was pronounced dead on arrival.

meanings.definition: If you say that a plan, idea, etc. is dead on arrival, you mean that it is certain to fail:
examples: The peace agreement is already dead on arrival.
Nine out of the ten scientists on the panel declared the proposal dead on arrival.

meanings.definition: a way of calculating the position of a ship or aircraft using only information about the direction and distance it has travelled from a known point
someone or something that looks very similar to someone or something else:
examples: He's a dead ringer for Bono from U2.

meanings.definition: someone or something that looks very similar to someone or something else:
examples: She's a dead ringer for Marilyn Monroe.

meanings.definition: a period during the year in which very few people want to buy a particular product or service:
examples: It was the dead season and most of the hotels were closed.

meanings.definition: to be completely opposed to something:
examples: He's dead set against living in the city.
UK You won't be able to change his mind - he's dead against the plan.
I'd like Millie to go back to college but she's dead set against the idea.
They are dead set against any form of legislation.
UK Sam is dead against anything that requires further investment.
I'd expressed an interest in finding my birth parents but my adoptive mother was dead set against it.

meanings.definition: to be very determined to do or have something:
examples: Martha's dead set on having a new bike.
Ethan is dead set on being an actor.
I'd like to travel around Europe this summer but Jacob is dead set on touring the US.
Her husband is dead set on expanding the business.
I don't think they should go ahead with the plan, but if they're dead set on it, there isn't much I can do.

meanings.definition: complete silence:
examples: The conductor waited for dead silence before commencing the performance.
There was dead silence in the room as the news sank in.

meanings.definition: the amount of space in the respiratory system (= the organs involved in breathing) where air is not taking part in gas exchange (= the process of taking in oxygen and releasing carbon dioxide), or the amount of air in this space, for example in the nose, mouth, or throat:
examples: Our data show a decreased respiratory efficiency together with an increased physiological dead space.
In COPD patients, this causes a significant increase in the respiratory dead space.

meanings.definition: a space left inside the body by a surgical procedure:
examples: The abdomen is closed in layers, taking care to close any dead space to avoid haematoma formation.
Sutures need to avoid creating dead spaces, which represent an ideal proliferation field for germs.

meanings.definition: an area, such as in a building, that is not being used, or not being used effectively:
examples: A good way of maximizing dead space is to install a shelf above the door.
This project is about brightening up the dead space of the stairwell.

meanings.definition: an amount of a product that a company has bought or made but is unable to sell. Storing dead stock costs money and so reduces the amount of profit a company can make:
examples: Under the rules you can discount the products after a year, but a year is a long time to keep dead stock.

meanings.definition: time when there is little or no activity:
examples: Investors often treat bear markets as dead time, figuring that there's nothing to do until the economy improves.

meanings.definition: in the act of doing something wrong or illegal:
examples: Even if a kid is caught dead to rights with alcohol, we can't punish him.

meanings.definition: the heaviness of a person or object that cannot or does not move by itself:
examples: She may be small but, when I have to carry her upstairs after she's fallen asleep, she's a dead weight (US also she is dead weight).

meanings.definition: a male writer or other famous person who may be highly respected because he was a white man who is no longer alive, rather than because his work deserves more respect than that of others:
examples: Students upset by the focus on “dead white males” demanded that the curriculum be replaced with one more inclusive toward women, minorities, and non-Western cultures.

meanings.definition: people or things that are no longer useful:
examples: She cleared out the dead wood as soon as she took over the company.

meanings.definition: people, esp. employees, who are no longer useful:
examples: When she took over the agency, she streamlined the operation by getting rid of a lot of dead wood.

meanings.definition: people or things that are no longer useful or effective:
examples: We think that 76% of all retail money is invested in funds which are effectively dead wood.

meanings.definition: a place where a mobile phone does not work because there is no signal
a place or time in which nothing happens:
examples: The village is a dead zone for many young people.

meanings.definition: in American football, the part of the field in the opponent's territory (= area of the field) that is too far from the end zone for the offence to try to kick a field goal:
examples: With his team in the dead zone, the coach had to make a tough decision whether or not to try for a first down.

meanings.definition: in American football, an action that is against the rules that occurs when the ball is not in the act of being thrown or carried in the field of play:
examples: The penalty counted as a dead-ball foul because the contact occurred after the referee had blown the whistle.
The wide receiver was flagged for unsportsmanlike conduct for taunting his opponent, a deadball foul that resulted in a penalty of 15 yards.
Every delivery counts unless a dead ball foul is declared.

meanings.definition: a job in which there is no chance of progressing to a better, more important job
a job which does not offer any opportunity for improving your situation:
examples: Despite having a degree in journalism, he got stuck in a dead-end job at an insurance company.

meanings.definition: completely accurate or correct:
examples: He amazed them all by making dead-on predictions.
She could do dead-on impressions of her boss.
"Is that a fair assessment?" "I think that's absolutely dead-on."

meanings.definition: used to describe someone or something that you like or think is good:
examples: He's a dead-on guy.
The meal was dead on.

meanings.definition: exactly:
examples: You're dead-on right about that.
The results were fifty-fifty, dead on.

meanings.definition: used as a way of emphasizing that you are serious or mean what you say:
examples: I was so confused by that last question on the test, I deadass thought I had to divide it by 3.
Some of the stuff people wrote was just dead-ass wrong.

meanings.definition: a person who is not willing to work, does not behave in a responsible way, and does not fit into ordinary society:
examples: He's a real deadbeat who's never had a proper job.

meanings.definition: a person or company that is not willing to pay debts or accept responsibility
not willing to pay debts or accept responsibilities:
examples: The new law is aimed at deadbeat landlords who owe $22 million.

meanings.definition: someone who owes money and does not pay it, or someone who avoids doing work
a person who tries to avoid paying money that they owe:
examples: I keep reminding my mortgage company that I'm not a deadbeat.

meanings.definition: a strong type of lock on a door that needs a key or a handle to open it
to make something less painful or less strong:
examples: Morphine is often used to deaden the pain of serious injuries.

meanings.definition: to reduce the severity or effect of something:
examples: He asked for some stronger medication to deaden the pain.

examples: He set American records for his age group in the squat, deadlift, and total lift.

meanings.definition: a time or day by which something must be done:
examples: There's no way I can meet that deadline.

I'm afraid you've missed the deadline - the deadline for applications was 30 May.

meanings.definition: a time or day by which something must be done:
examples: The deadline for filing income taxes is April 15th.

meanings.definition: the time or date by which something must be done:
examples: The application deadline is February 16.
We have already agreed a deadline of July 1 2011.
900,000 applications were handed in by yesterday's noon deadline.
The deadline for bids was yesterday lunchtime.
They have been given a 12-month deadline to create a plan for the region.

We hit delays and asked to extend the deadline.
If you miss the deadline your application cannot be considered.
The deadline was looming and things were getting tense in the office.

meanings.definition: a situation in which agreement in an argument cannot be reached because neither side will change its demands or accept any of the demands of the other side:
examples: Somebody will have to compromise if we are to break (= end) the deadlock between the two warring factions.
The talks are aimed at ending the deadlock between the two groups.
Once again the talks have ended in deadlock.
Deadlock over wage levels has prevented an agreement being reached.

meanings.definition: a situation in a sports game, competition, etc. where neither side is winning:
examples: Watkins broke the deadlock after 53 minutes with a goal from a corner kick.
The fencing champion ended a 5-5 deadlock with just a few seconds to go to claim the gold medal.
Their second chess game ended in deadlock.

meanings.definition: a lock that is inside the edge of a door, so that it cannot be seen or removed when the door is closed
a state or situation in which agreement in an argument cannot be reached because neither side will change its demands or accept the demands of the other side:
examples: The long deadlock over clean air legislation has been broken.

meanings.definition: a situation in which people cannot agree and no progress can be made:
examples: There was deadlock between the directors and the negotiating committee.
The deadlock in the talks meant that the dispute was taken to arbitration.

meanings.definition: a loss that occurs when a government raises taxes in order to get more money, but then loses money as a result. For example, a company that goes bankrupt because of increased taxes will stop paying taxes completely:

If a very loud noise deafens you, it makes you deaf, or makes you temporarily unable to hear the other sounds near you:

meanings.definition: (of a sound) extremely loud:

meanings.definition: silence or lack of response, when people expect you to speak or act:

meanings.definition: in an extremely loud way:

meanings.definition: If you are deafeningly silent, you do not respond, or you stay silent when people expect you to speak or act:

meanings.definition: an unwillingness to listen, or a lack of understanding about something:

meanings.definition: the act of dealing (= sharing out) something, especially playing cards:

meanings.definition: a good, or lower than usual, price:

meanings.definition: money that a person's company, or pension company, pays to their family or another person when they die:

meanings.definition: a warning of the end of something:

the number of people who die in a particular group or area in a particular period of time. This figure is often used by insurance companies to calculate risk:

meanings.definition: the place in a prison where prisoners wait to be killed as punishment

meanings.definition: something that leads to someone's death or the complete destruction of someone or something:
examples: According to the law of the gangs, to quit is to sign your own death warrant.
America must address those shared resentments or risk signing its death warrant as a superpower.

meanings.definition: a desire for death:
examples: He takes so many chances that you'd think he had a death wish.

meanings.definition: a picture of a human skull (= the hard structure of the head) used as a warning of danger or to frighten people
very dangerous:
examples: a death-defying leap from an aircraft

meanings.definition: the bed that someone dies in or is dying in:
examples: She spoke to her family from her deathbed.

meanings.definition: lasting for ever and never to be forgotten:
examples: his deathless prose

meanings.definition: in a way that will last for ever and never be forgotten:
examples: In this film, it's difficult to work out who's good, who's bad, and who's deathlessly loyal.
A revival of his deathlessly charming ballet will brighten the summer schedule.

meanings.definition: extreme in a way that is unpleasant:
examples: After he had spoken, a deathly silence fell on the room.
The artillery bombardment was followed by a deathly hush in the trenches.
Everyone had gone and the house was deathly quiet.
She went deathly pale.

meanings.definition: seeming like death:
examples: Madeline looked deathly pale.
The crowd was deathly silent.

meanings.definition: something that is very dangerous and could cause death:
examples: With no fire exits, the hall was a deathtrap.

meanings.definition: an insect that eats wood, especially in old houses, causing serious damage

informal for
        
         debutante

abbreviation for 
        
         debenture

abbreviation for 
        
         debit
a complete failure, especially because of bad planning and organization:
examples: The collapse of the company was described as the greatest financial debacle in US history.

meanings.definition: an event or situation that is a complete failure:
examples: The candidate’s behavior during the debate turned what could have been a victory into a political debacle.

meanings.definition: (of a bank) to close someone's account because they are regarded as a risk legally, financially, or to the bank's reputation:
examples: Individuals and organizations involved in politically sensitive issues, such as criticism of human rights abuses, may find that they are debanked as a consequence of their campaigning.
One individual told us that he has been de-banked six times in 10 years.

meanings.definition: the act by a bank of closing someone's account because they are regarded as a risk legally, financially, or to the bank's reputation:
examples: The government promised tougher rules on debanking to protect customers' freedom of speech.
Unfortunately, the practice of de-banking without explanation or the possibility of appeal continues.

meanings.definition: to stop someone from doing something by law or by official agreement:
examples: He was debarred from the club for unacceptable behaviour.

meanings.definition: to stop someone from doing something by law or by official agreement:
examples: He was debarred from the club for unacceptable behaviour.
All of them were debarred from entering the country for five years.

meanings.definition: to leave a ship, aircraft, etc. after a journey:
examples: We boarded a train, and an hour later we debarked on the outskirts of the city.

meanings.definition: to remove bark (= the hard outer covering) from a tree:
examples: Cork trees are debarked every nine years to make wine bottle corks.

meanings.definition: to make something less good or less valuable:
examples: Some argue that money has debased football.
We debase language by using it inappropriately until it loses its meaning.

meanings.definition: to make someone morally worse or less deserving of respect:
examples: War debases those who take part in it.
He would not debase himself by entering such a popularity contest.

meanings.definition: to reduce in quality or value:
examples: Television is often blamed for debasing American politics.

meanings.definition: to lower the value of money, for instance by making metal coins from a less valuable substance, borrowing too much against the current value of that money, etc. :
examples: The only way out of this is to debase the currency.
In the last years of his reign, he spent huge sums on war and debased the coinage of the empire.
Desperate governments down the ages have always debased the currency.
The currency had been debased, leading to violent inflation.
Charles had threatened to debase the coinage by reminting it.

meanings.definition: worse than before, especially morally; less valuable or deserving less respect than before:
examples: He believes that acts of torture reveal how debased we are.
Our world view has become debased. We no longer have a sense of the sacred.

meanings.definition: the action of reducing the quality or value of something:
examples: The Government claims that academic standards will be protected from further debasement.
Currency debasement means that the more dollars there are in circulation, the less each dollar is worth.

meanings.definition: a reduction in the value of coins which is made by reducing the amount of pure metal such as gold or silver they contain, done in the past so that more coins could be produced

present participle of 
        
         debase
to make something less good or less valuable:
examples: Some argue that money has debased football.
We debase language by using it inappropriately until it loses its meaning.

meanings.definition: to make someone morally worse or less deserving of respect:
examples: War debases those who take part in it.
He would not debase himself by entering such a popularity contest.

meanings.definition: not clear or certain because different people may have different opinions:
examples: It's debatable whether a university degree helps at all.
The value of some of the experiments is debatable.

meanings.definition: not clear, not certain, or not fixed; possibly not true:
examples: It’s debatable whether he could get a fair trial here.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not clear or certain, because different people may have different opinions:
examples: His latest documentary is debatably the least controversial.
The breakup of the organization is debatably overdue and will be good for democracy.

meanings.definition: (a) serious discussion of a subject in which many people take part:
examples: Education is the current focus of public debate.
How we proceed from here is a matter for debate.
Over the years we have had several debates about future policy.

meanings.definition: a competition in which teams of people, often students, discuss a subject and the team that is judged to make the best arguments wins:
examples: The team won their Round 3 debate against Mitcham Girls High School.
The students were taking part in a debate contest.

meanings.definition: to discuss a subject in a formal way:
examples: In Parliament today, MPs debated the Finance Bill.
They had been debating for several hours without reaching a conclusion.
The authorities debated whether to build a new car park.

meanings.definition: to try to make a decision about something:
examples: We debated whether to take the earlier train.
I'm still debating what colour to paint the walls.

meanings.definition: a discussion, esp. one in which several people with different opinions about something discuss them seriously, or the process of discussing something:
examples: Education is always a topic of interest and public debate.

meanings.definition: a serious discussion, or a period of discussion about a subject, in which many people take part:
examples: The debate about food safety has engaged the whole nation.
Over the years we have had several debates about future policy.

meanings.definition: a group of school or college students who take part in competitive debates (= formal discussions of a subject):
examples: In school she was a successful member of the debate team.

meanings.definition: a person who takes part in a serious discussion of a subject with many other people:
examples: She was a good speaker and an excellent debater.
He had been a keen debater in his school and college days.

meanings.definition: a group of school, college, or university students who take part in competitive debates (= formal discussions of a subject):
examples: I was captain of the debating team at school, so a logical and well-expressed argument impresses me.

meanings.definition: to destroy or damage something so that it is no longer considered good or moral:
examples: Lenin said that the best way to destroy the capitalist system was to debauch the currency.

meanings.definition: made weaker or destroyed by bad sexual behaviour, drinking too much alcohol, taking drugs, etc.:
examples: his debauched lifestyle

meanings.definition: a debauched person (= one who drinks too much alcohol, takes drugs, shows bad sexual behaviour, etc.):
examples: He gave a convincing stage performance as the unpleasant young debauchee.
He was condemned as a 'scandalous debauchee'.

meanings.definition: bad sexual behaviour, drinking too much alcohol, taking drugs, etc.:
examples: a life of debauchery

meanings.definition: to remove the part that looks like hair from shellfish (= sea creatures that live in shells and are eaten as food) before cooking them:
examples: Debeard and wash the mussels, and rinse the other fish.
First, clean and de-beard your mussels.

meanings.definition: a type of loan, often used by companies to raise money, that is paid back over a long period of time and at a fixed rate of interest

a type of loan, often used by companies to raise money, that is paid back over a long period of time and at a fixed rate of interest. In the UK, but not in the US, debentures are secured against property or other assets owned by the borrower:
examples: Investors in Wimbledon debentures get a free seat during the annual tournament.
A fixed debenture is secured on a named asset, similar to a mortgage that is secured on a person's house.
hold/issue/secure a debenture

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         debenture
a person or company that has lent money to another person or company by using a debenture:
examples: Payment of interest is made to the debenture holder at a specified rate and at clearly defined intervals.

meanings.definition: an amount of money paid regularly to the lenders on debentures:
examples: Debenture interest has to be paid by a company whether it makes a profit or not.

meanings.definition: a type of stock or share in which the owner receives regular payments of interest instead of dividends
to make someone or something physically weak:
examples: Chemotherapy exhausted and debilitated him.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         debilitate
to make someone or something physically weak:
examples: Chemotherapy exhausted and debilitated him.

meanings.definition: making someone or something physically weak:
examples: a debilitating condition/disease
Diabetes can be severely debilitating or even life-threatening if not treated regularly.

meanings.definition: causing weakness:
examples: Strokes are a common debilitating condition of old age.

meanings.definition: physical weakness
(a record of) money taken out of a bank account:
examples: The account was in debit at the end of the month (= more money had been spent than was in the account at that time).
Debits are shown in the left-hand column.

meanings.definition: to take money out of an account or keep a record of this:
examples: The bank debited my account.
The bank debited the money from my account.
The unauthorized borrowing fee will be debited to your account.

meanings.definition: money taken out of a financial account, or a record of money taken
an amount of money that is taken out of a bank account, etc.:
examples: Once your contract with them ends, the company should no longer take monthly debits from your account.
The statement showed a debit of £350 on January 22.

meanings.definition: the system of taking money from a bank account, etc., for example, by using a debit card:
examples: When you swipe your card at the checkout line, you'll be asked if you want to pay by debit or credit.
debit payment/transaction/purchase
I had lost the original invoice but I still had the debit receipt.

meanings.definition: an amount recorded that is recorded in a company's financial accounts which represents money that has been used to pay an expense or buy an asset. In double-entry bookkeeping debits are recorded on the left-hand side (= the debit side) of the accounts:
examples: One of the principles of accounting is that the debits recorded in a ledger should equal or balance the credits in it.

meanings.definition: to take or pay money out of a bank account, etc.:
examples: Your account will be debited as soon as your order has been shipped.
By agreeing to these conditions, you give permission for us to debit your credit card with the amount stated above.
She later discovered that the bank had accidentally debited $517.23 from her account twice.

meanings.definition: to record an amount in a company's financial accounts which represents money that has been used to pay an expense or buy an asset. In double-entry bookkeeping this is done on the left-hand side (= the debit side) of the accounts.
an account at a store or business which you pay money into, so when you buy their goods or services, the store can take money from your account as payment:
examples: Simply make a deposit into your debit account, then present your card at participating locations.

meanings.definition: an amount of money in a bank account, etc. which is less than zero because more money was taken out of it than the total amount that was paid into it:
examples: Customers should consider transferring the debit balance to a credit card with a special rate for debt transfers.

meanings.definition: the amount, shown in the record of a company’s finances, by which its total debits are greater than its total credits:
examples: Debit balances may arise due to timing differences, in which case income will be accrued at the year end to offset the debit.

meanings.definition: a small plastic card that can be used as a method of payment, the money being taken from your bank account automatically:
examples: I paid with my debit card.

meanings.definition: a small plastic card used to make a payment by taking the amount of the payment automatically from your bank account:
examples: The supermarket takes debit cards, credit cards, cash, and checks.

meanings.definition: a small plastic card that you can use to get cash from cash machines, or to pay for goods and services. When you use the card, the money is taken directly from your bank account:
examples: Make online payments using your MasterCard or Visa debit card.
Debit card payments will incur a small handling fee.
Can I pay by debit card?
All debit card transactions will be in pounds sterling.

meanings.definition: the list of numbers that shows amounts of money that have been spent from a bank account
a document sent to a customer when money is owed from their account, for example, because of a mistake on an invoice:
examples: A debit or credit memo is received from the bank each time an adjustment is made to the State’s bank accounts.
Many larger companies adopt the procedure of raising a debit note for any errors on invoices.

meanings.definition: to take money out of an account:
examples: The bank debited the money from my account.
I was concerned that she had debited funds from the club's account without authorization.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         debit
to take money out of an account or keep a record of this:
examples: The bank debited my account.
The bank debited the money from my account.
The unauthorized borrowing fee will be debited to your account.

examples: The bank debited my account.

meanings.definition: (especially of men) attractive, confident, and carefully dressed:
examples: a debonair appearance/manner
a debonair young man

meanings.definition: in an attractive, confident, and carefully dressed way:
examples: He delivered a charming performance as the debonairly cunning salesman.
He strode debonairly into the room with a condescending look on his face.

meanings.definition: a treatment in which dead tissue is removed from wounds such as burns in order to help them get better:
examples: chemical debridement

meanings.definition: to question someone in detail about work they have done for you:
examples: The pilots were thoroughly debriefed after every mission.
a debriefing session

meanings.definition: to question someone in detail to get useful information about something that person has done for you:
examples: After every flight, engineers thoroughly debrief the test pilot.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         debrief
to question someone in detail about work they have done for you:
examples: The pilots were thoroughly debriefed after every mission.
a debriefing session

meanings.definition: a meeting that takes place in order to get information about a particular piece of work that has been finished, for example about what was done successfully and what was not:
examples: debriefing sessions

meanings.definition: broken or torn pieces of something larger:
examples: Debris from the aircraft was scattered over a large area.

meanings.definition: broken or torn pieces left from the destruction of something larger:
examples: After the tornado, debris from damaged trees and houses littered the town.

meanings.definition: something, especially money, that is owed to someone else, or the state of owing something:
examples: He managed to pay off his debts in two years.
The company ran up huge debts.
They are in debt to (= owe money to) the bank.
He got into debt (= borrowed money) after he lost his job.
The company is deep in debt (= owes a lot of money).

meanings.definition: something owed, esp. money:
examples: He managed to pay off his debts in two years.

meanings.definition: If you are in debt, you owe money:
examples: We seem to be perpetually in debt.

meanings.definition: If you go into debt, you borrow money.
the amount of money that is owed by a person, company, country, etc. and that they usually have to pay interest on:
examples: Financing will consist of $200 million of debt in the form of a five-year term loan.
Companies become insolvent because they cannot pay their debts.
Investors fear the insurance company will have amassed debts of more than €22.5 million by the end of the year.
When applying for a loan, customers may be required to prove their ability to repay the debt.
The country's foreign exchange reserves were adequate to settle the entire debt this year.
Our credit counselors will work with you to help you to reduce your debt.
The plan also includes restructuring of long-term debts at lower interest rates.
State law allows cities to write off uncollectable debts with the approval of the city council.
If the market does not improve, these businesses may not be able to service their debts, and we may see more bankruptcies.
This arrangement is useful for those who need to consolidate their debts .
Young college graduates are saddled with crippling debts.

meanings.definition: the situation of owing money, or of not having enough money to pay what you owe:
examples: Consumer debt is high, with record-level defaults on credit cards and mortgage loans.
Now solvent, the conglomerate was $14 billion in debt when Jones took over as the new CEO.
With college tuition and housing prices rising, more and more families are falling into debt.
By setting up a debt repayment plan he was able to pay off his creditors and stay out of debt for good.

meanings.definition: the process of making a new legal agreement so a person, company, etc. which is in financial difficulties can pay back its debt more easily. The agreement includes new plans about how, when, and to whom money should be paid:
examples: a debt adjustment plan

meanings.definition: a legal agreement between a debtor (= person, company, etc. that owes money) and their creditors, which includes a new plan for paying back the debt:
examples: In Australia a Part IX debt agreement is a legally binding agreement between a debtor and their creditors, and is only to be used where the debtor is insolvent.

meanings.definition: a method for paying off a debt which involves the person, company, etc. that owes the money paying regular amounts over a period of time:
examples: long-term debt amortization schedules
a debt amortization calendar

meanings.definition: the process of helping companies that owe or are owed money to find an acceptable agreement for paying back the debt:
examples: For creditors, debt arbitration makes it possible to recoup more of the amount owed than would be possible by filing a suit against the debtor.

meanings.definition: a person whose job is to solve financial problems between companies by helping them make new arrangements for paying back a debt:
examples: Debt arbitrators work with the debtor and his creditors to develop a repayment schedule that is agreeable to all parties.

meanings.definition: an amount of money that was owed on a particular date, which was paid late or has still not been paid:
examples: Clearing external debt arrears will be a critical step in the country’s economic recovery.

meanings.definition: the amount of debt owed by a person, company, or country:
examples: The EU is participating in the initiative to ease the debt burden of the highly indebted poorer countries of the world.
The company announced yesterday that it plans to sell off various parts of the business to reduce a debt burden of about $18bn.

meanings.definition: a measurement of the amount of money that a person or company can borrow and pay back during a particular period without any financial difficulty:
examples: Changes in revenue and interest rates can affect the value of a firm and its optimal debt capacity.

meanings.definition: money that a company borrows from banks, investors, etc. which is calculated as part of the company’s total capital:
examples: In that year the total supply of debt capital available for commercial real estate financing was $750 billion.
The commercial bank reorganised its debt capital markets business.

meanings.definition: the job of collecting payments from people who have failed to pay the money they owe for goods, services, etc. that they have already received:
examples: We specialize in debt collection and related credit management services.
a debt collection agency/service

meanings.definition: a person or company that collects payments from people who have failed to pay the money they owe:
examples: After she became overdrawn, the bank closed her account and threatened her with debt collectors, credit reference agencies and court action to recover the cash.

meanings.definition: a method used for managing debt, in which you take out a single new loan and use it to pay back several of your other debts:
examples: The OFT said that the majority of debt consolidation loans took the form of a second mortgage.

meanings.definition: a company that provides services for managing debt, for example, a single new loan that is used for paying back several smaller debts:
examples: Our debt consolidators will help your reduce interest charges, to lower your monthly credit card payments.

meanings.definition: the activity of giving people financial help and advice about managing debt, for example, helping them plan better ways to pay back money that they owe:
examples: Free help is available from debt counselling services.

meanings.definition: a person whose job is to give financial advice and help to people so they can pay or manage their debts more successfully:
examples: After a payment schedule is set up the debt counselor will talk to your creditors and ask them to reduce your interest rates.

meanings.definition: a measurement used to decide whether a person, company, or country can afford to pay back a loan, calculated by dividing the income that is available by the total amount of payments owed each year for the loan:
examples: A debt coverage ratio of less than 1 indicates that there is not enough cash flow to pay the property's expenses and mortgage payments.

meanings.definition: the situation in which collateral (= property that will be sold or collected to make certain a debt is paid) becomes less valuable:
examples: The effects of a bust will be rising unemployment, followed by bad debts, then debt deflation, and then finally falling asset prices.

meanings.definition: the degree to which a company or country risks losing money because it has lent money that may not be paid back:
examples: Investors are becoming increasingly worried about the insurance industry’s debt exposure to bank bonds.

meanings.definition: the fact of removing a debt from a company’s financial records because it has been paid back or no longer exists:
examples: The conversion of the debentures to Series A Stock resulted in a debt extinguishment loss of $1,048,000.

meanings.definition: a financial arrangement in which a factoring company takes responsibility for collecting money relating to a business's invoices, and immediately pays that business part of the total amount owed on the invoices:
examples: Debt factoring is a powerful tool that businesses can use to improve cash flow.

meanings.definition: money that a company or government borrows in order to do business or finance its activities, for example by selling bonds, taking out loans, or using credit:
examples: Most of the money for developing the new plant will come from debt finance.

meanings.definition: a legal agreement in which someone promises to pay a loan or other debt if the person or organization that borrowed the money fails to pay
a type of debt, such as a bond, that is offered as an investment and that includes a written promise to pay back the investor by a particular time:
examples: Up to 35% of the Fund’s assets may be invested in short-term debt instruments to meet anticipated day-to-day operating expenses.

meanings.definition: a company’s use of loans and other debts to pay for investments or to operate its business:
examples: Companies can prop up their profitability by taking on more debt leverage.

meanings.definition: the amount of debt that a person, company, or country has, especially in relation to their ability to pay it back:
examples: carry/cut/reduce a debt load
Consumers are carrying heavy debt loads and facing skimpy wage increases.

meanings.definition: methods used to reduce or pay back debts, or services provided to help people do this:
examples: a debt management company/firm
They offer a debt management plan allowing you to pay a fixed sum each month, which is then divided among your creditors.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         moratorium

US spelling of 
        
         debt of honour
money that someone owes that they cannot be forced by law to pay back, but that they have a moral duty to pay back:
examples: He had pledged to repay a debt of honour of £110,000 outstanding since 1979.

meanings.definition: something such as thanks, praise, or a reward that is owed to someone because of their good actions:
examples: He said that he owed a debt of honour to the man who kept him sane during his captivity.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a country, company, or organization owes more money than it can pay back so that it cannot afford to make new investments:
examples: Debt overhang in the US leaves it more vulnerable to the next downturn in the economy.
This study examines the impact of debt overhangs on agricultural trade.

meanings.definition: the act of paying back money that you have borrowed:
examples: Many people are struggling to meet their debt payments.
The country announced a moratorium whereby its foreign debt payment was suspended for 12 months.
a debt payment plan/programme

meanings.definition: a system for measuring a country's, company's, or organization's ability to pay back its debts and any interest on those debts:
examples: The group's debt rating was downgraded from A- to BBB+.
They announced that the company's debt rating had been raised to 'investment grade'.
debt rating system

meanings.definition: the value of the goods and services that a country produces, compared with the amount of debt it has, used as a way of measuring how successful the economy of a particular country is:
examples: In some countries debt ratios exceed 100% of GDP.

meanings.definition: a measurement of a company's ability to borrow money and pay it back, that is calculated by dividing the total amount of all kinds of debt that is owed by the amount that shareholders have invested. This method can be used by investors to decide whether or not to invest in a company:
examples: The company has a healthy balance sheet, with strong cash flow and low debt ratios.

meanings.definition: the process of making people or companies pay the money that they owe to other people or companies, when they have not paid back the debt at the time that was arranged:
examples: When problems arise, professional debt recovery has proved to be an effective way of regaining lost money.

meanings.definition: the process of paying back part of a debt:
examples: a debt reduction programme/plan/initiative

meanings.definition: the act of borrowing more money in order to pay a debt that you already have:
examples: The crisis was averted with an £840m debt refinancing package.

meanings.definition: the situation in which a bank or a government tells a person, a company, or a government that they do not have to pay back the money they owe:
examples: There are plans to provide full debt relief for some African countries.

meanings.definition: the situation when a foreign country is allowed to reduce or not pay back the money that it owes to a government or bank:
examples: a debt relief programme/plan/package
Last year several countries received billions of dollars in debt relief.
In order to qualify for debt relief, countries must fulfil a set of conditions.

meanings.definition: the process of paying a debt over a longer period of time than originally agreed, or paying back less than the original debt:
examples: The debt renegotiation process may entail many changes: extension of maturity date, changes in interest rates, etc.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         debt restructuring
the situation when a debt is paid back over a longer period of time than was originally agreed:
examples: The creditors of the cash-strapped electronics group are set to agree on debt rescheduling and a temporary freeze on debt repayments.

meanings.definition: the process of changing the form of a company's or country's debt so that it can pay what it owes later, and continue to operate:
examples: Economists warn that some form of devaluation or debt restructuring may eventually be necessary.

meanings.definition: an agreement in which a company or government that has lent money to another company or country allows it to pay back its debt in a different way or at a later time than was originally agreed:
examples: a debt restructuring plan/deal/proposal

meanings.definition: the fact of paying back a debt completely, so that it no longer exists:
examples: Many experts argue in favour of rapid debt retirement.
There are costs associated with early debt retirements.

meanings.definition: a financial document such as a bond, debenture, etc. that shows that money is owed and that the borrower promises to pay it back on a certain date at an agreed rate of interest:
examples: short-term/long-term debt securities

meanings.definition: the act of regularly paying back a debt, including interest:
examples: debt service costs/payments

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         debt coverage ratio
a financial agreement between a borrower and a lender in which the borrower pays back less than the full amount of a debt and the lender agrees to accept this as full payment:
examples: Debt settlement companies, which offer to arrange debt settlements for borrowers, often require a big payment upfront for their services.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         debt-equity swap  :
examples: He used a debt swap to buy a 30% stake in the privatized telephone company.

meanings.definition: a financial arrangement in which the cost of lending a large sum of money is shared by a number of different banks, investment firms, etc.:
examples: We are an advisory firm which specializes in offering private equity and debt syndication services to entrepreneurs, corporates and investors.

meanings.definition: an agreement in which a company offers shares to its creditors (= banks and organizations that lend it money) so they will reduce the amount of its debt:
examples: The debt-for-equity swap could create more than 1.5 billion new shares.

meanings.definition: a financial arrangement in which a country's government gives local currency, shares, etc. to foreign investors who agree to pay part of the government’s foreign debts:
examples: The Treasury Secretary needs to establish a viable debt-equity swap program if it hopes to attract private foreign capital.

meanings.definition: used to describe an investment that you pay for by borrowing money:
examples: The company had a weaker overall financial profile after the debt-financed acquisition of another leading food business.

meanings.definition: used to describe a situation in which shareholders in a company are given bonds to replace their shares:
examples: Its lenders agreed to a debt-for-equity swap to save the company.
The company extended its debt-for-equity offer for a further day in order to raise the level of support for the crucial deal.

meanings.definition: not owing money:
examples: The company's virtually debt-free status gives it the flexibility to consider larger deals.

meanings.definition: owing a lot of money or involving a lot of debt:
examples: debt-laden consumers
Analysts warn that house prices could crash in this debt-laden property market.

meanings.definition: having a lot of debt and therefore in financial difficulty:
examples: a debt-ridden country/economy

a measurement of how financially successful a company is, that is calculated by dividing the total amount of a company's debts by the value of its assets:
examples: If a company's debt/asset ratio is low, it means that its assets are financed more through equity than by debt.

meanings.definition: a company's debt as a percentage of its capital as a whole, used to calculate if it has borrowed too much, if it can borrow more, etc.:
examples: The company has a financial policy of maintaining a net debt/capital ratio which does not exceed 45%.

meanings.definition: a measurement of a company's ability to borrow and pay back money that is calculated by dividing the amount of debt that it owes by the total value of its shares. The measurement changes as the value of the shares goes up and down:
examples: The debt/capitalization ratio is a commonly used measure of the strength of a company's capital structure.

meanings.definition: a method of measuring a company's ability to borrow and pay back money that is calculated by dividing the total amount of long-term debt by the amount that shareholders have invested. This method can be used by investors to decide whether or not to invest in a company:
examples: If the debt/equity ratio is greater than 1, assets are mostly financed through debt; if less than 1, assets are mostly financed through equity.
The company’s debt-to-equity ratio stood at 0.60:1 and was one of the best among its global peers.

meanings.definition: someone who owes money
a country, organization, or person who owes money:

meanings.definition: a person, country, or organization that owes money:

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         debtor nation
a country that owes more to other countries than other countries owe to it:
examples: The heavy foreign buying of U.S. securities flipped the U.S. over from creditor to debtor nation a few years ago.

meanings.definition: in the US, a financial arrangement in which a company that cannot pay its debts is given a loan so that it can continue to own and control its own assets and continue trading:
examples: Debtor-in-possession financing is intended to give companies the time and resources they need to be successful in the future.

meanings.definition: the process of stopping or reducing carbon gases, especially carbon dioxide, being released into the atmosphere as the result of a process, for example the burning of fossil fuels:
examples: "The solution to the climate challenge is decarbonization," he states.

meanings.definition: the process of removing carbon or material containing carbon from a substance or from an object, such as an engine:

meanings.definition: to stop or reduce carbon gases, especially carbon dioxide, being released into the atmosphere as the result of a process, for example the burning of fossil fuels:

meanings.definition: (an act of) keeping the truth hidden, especially to get an advantage:
examples: The story is about theft, fraud, and deceit on an incredible scale.

meanings.definition: speech or behavior that keeps the truth hidden:
examples: All we hear from them are lies and deceit.

meanings.definition: dishonest or illegal methods used by a person or organization in order to get something or to make people believe that something is true when it is not:

meanings.definition: dishonest or hiding the truth:
examples: deceitful behaviour

meanings.definition: in a way that keeps the truth hidden, especially to get an advantage:
examples: They deceitfully made big promises that they now cannot keep.

meanings.definition: the action of keeping the truth hidden, especially to get an advantage:

meanings.definition: easily deceived or tricked, and too willing to believe what other people say:
examples: His friends are so silly and deceivable.

meanings.definition: able to deceive, or causing someone to believe something that is not true:
examples: Maps are based upon the deceivable reports of other people.

meanings.definition: to persuade someone that something false is the truth, or to keep the truth hidden from someone for your own advantage:
examples: The company deceived customers by selling old computers as new ones.

meanings.definition: to persuade someone that something false is the truth; trick or fool:

meanings.definition: If you deceive yourself, you pretend something is true:

meanings.definition: to use dishonest or illegal methods to get something or to make people believe that something is true when it is not:

meanings.definition: to persuade someone to do something or believe something by not telling them the truth:

meanings.definition: relating to the Decembrists:

meanings.definition: behaviour that is good, moral, and acceptable in society:

meanings.definition: happening every ten years:

meanings.definition: in a way that happens every ten years:

meanings.definition: socially acceptable or good:

meanings.definition: dressed or wearing clothes:

meanings.definition: infml Decent also means wearing socially acceptable clothing:

meanings.definition: the act or process of decentralizing an organization or government (= moving control from a single place to several smaller ones):

meanings.definition: to move the operations of a business or other organization from a single, central place to several smaller ones:

meanings.definition: if a large company or organization decentralizes or is decentralized, its activities are moved from one large central place to several different, smaller places:

to choose something, especially after thinking carefully about several possibilities:
examples: They have to decide by next Friday.
It doesn't matter to me which one we have - you decide.
In the end, we decided to go to the theatre.
She decided (that) she would travel to India.
I can't decide what to do.
He can't decide whether to buy it.
The committee decided in favour of (= made a formal judgment to choose) the cheapest option.

meanings.definition: to be the reason or situation that makes a particular result happen:
examples: The weather decided the outcome of the tennis match.
Tim's mistake decided the game (= caused him to lose).

meanings.definition: to choose between one possibility or another:
examples: I decided I would try it.
In the end, we decided to go to the theater.
We’re trying to decide how to proceed.
He decided (that) it was his business.

meanings.definition: If something decides a result in a competition, it causes that result:
examples: A mistake by our team decided the game against us.

meanings.definition: A deciding factor is something so important that it forces a particular decision:
examples: The deciding factor in choosing this school was that it was far from home.

meanings.definition: to choose something or someone after careful thought:
examples: I've decided on blue for the bathroom.

meanings.definition: certain, obvious, or easy to notice:
examples: She had a decided advantage over her opponent.

meanings.definition: clear; certain:
examples: There’s been a decided improvement in subway service.

meanings.definition: certainly and obviously:
examples: He was decidedly careful about what he told me.

meanings.definition: a final game or competition that allows one person or team to win, or the winning point scored:
examples: They lost what was regarded as the championship decider at Leeds.

meanings.definition: a person who makes the decisions in a particular situation:
examples: The president is the decider in these matters.

meanings.definition: A deciding event or action is more important than the rest because the final result, decision, or choice is changed by it:
examples: The environmental argument was a deciding factor.

Glennon scored the deciding goal in the final minute of the match.

meanings.definition: a fact or situation that is more important than others in producing a final result, decision, or choice:

meanings.definition: a vote that decides a matter:
examples: In the end, it was my daughter who cast what was probably the deciding vote.

to make a country that was previously a colony (= a country controlled by another country) politically independent; to get rid of colonies:

meanings.definition: to change something such as a curriculum (= a list of books, ideas, etc. to be studied) in a way that considers the cultural beliefs behind it, for example the belief that European writers, artists, or ideas are better and more important than ones from countries that were colonized (= controlled) by Europe, and that gives more importance to these non-European writers, artists, etc.:
examples: Decolonizing the curriculum asks us to look at our shared assumptions about how the world is, particularly assumptions regarding racial and civilizational hierarchy.

The police have deduced that he must have left his apartment yesterday evening.

meanings.definition: to reach an answer by thinking about a general truth and its relationship to a specific situation:
examples: In an attempt to deduce what happened to the jet, investigators are looking at other similar planes.

meanings.definition: to believe that something is the case after thinking carefully about a particular fact:
examples: What did they deduce from the evidence?
We cannot deduce very much from these figures.

meanings.definition: the process by which a person selling a property proves to the buyer that they own it:
examples: While buyers can obtain such information direct, it is usual for the seller to provide it under a process known as deducing title.

meanings.definition: to take away an amount or part from a total:
examples: The player had points deducted from his score for arguing with the referee.
Money is deducted from your account each time your car passes through the toll booths.
Employers deduct the tax from employee salaries.

meanings.definition: to take away an amount or part from a total:
examples: The company deducts $31.93 each week from my salary for health insurance.

meanings.definition: To deduct is also not to have to pay taxes on an amount that you have earned:
examples: Homeowners can deduct the interest they pay on their mortgages.

meanings.definition: to take away an amount or part from a total:
examples: By arrangement with your mortgage holder, you can have them automatically deduct a regular payment from a checking or savings account.
Each week a small amount is deducted from her wages for the pension plan.
Tax and National Insurance contributions are deducted at source, before you receive your salary.

meanings.definition: to take away the cost of particular things from the amount of money that you have earned, before you pay tax on it:
examples: There are many expenses you can deduct from your income before calculating tax.
