meanings.definition: an amount of money that you are responsible for paying before your insurance (= protection against loss) will pay you for an expense:
examples: Judy’s car insurance policy had a $500 deductible.

meanings.definition: A deductible expense is a cost that you can subtract from the earnings on which you have to pay income tax:
examples: Mortgage interest is deductible.

meanings.definition: relating to an amount or part that can be taken away from a total:
examples: However, the supplementary benefit that he was receiving was deductible from the figure awarded as damages.

meanings.definition: relating to particular costs that can be taken away from the amount of money that you have earned, before you have to pay tax on it:
examples: Expenditure by private persons on education and training is rarely deductible for income-tax purposes.
deductible expenses

meanings.definition: an amount of money that is taken away from the money paid to an employee before it is given to them:
examples: The increase in the deductible could eat away a worker's entire pay increase for the year.

meanings.definition: a part of the cost of an accident, loss, injury, etc. that you agree to pay yourself when you buy insurance:
examples: The company's insurance covers the cost of accidents, minus a $500 deductible, for members of all ages.

meanings.definition: the calculation of taking an amount or a part of something away from a total or the amount that is taken away:

meanings.definition: an amount that is taken away from the money you are paid before you officially receive it:
examples: After deductions, his taxable income is $30,000.

meanings.definition: the process of learning something by considering a general set of facts and thinking about how something specific relates to them:
examples: Sherlock Holmes was famous for making clever deductions.

meanings.definition: an amount or part taken away from a total, esp. an expense that you do not have to pay taxes on, or the process of taking away an amount or part:
examples: New tax regulations would cut the deduction for business lunches.

meanings.definition: the process of taking away an amount or a part of something from a total, or the amount that is taken:
examples: The interest you receive will be paid after deduction of tax.
The tax and social security authorities normally insist upon deduction of payments and contributions at source.
Household insurance policies tend to replace lost or stolen items on a "new for old" basis, while travel policies tend to make deductions for wear and tear.

meanings.definition: the process of taking away particular costs from the amount of money that you have earned before you pay tax on it, or the costs that are taken away:
examples: The married couple's allowance was in the form of a tax deduction.

meanings.definition: reaching an answer or a decision by thinking carefully about the known facts:
examples: a deductive argument
deductive logic/reasoning

meanings.definition: in a way that reaches an answer or a decision by thinking carefully about the known facts:
examples: Scientific textbooks are usually written deductively.
Her argument proceeds from accepted principles to conclusions that follow deductively from them.

meanings.definition: an intentional act, especially a very bad or very good one:
examples: It seems to me that a lot of evil deeds are done in the name of religion.
She's always helping people and doing good deeds.

meanings.definition: a legal document that is an official record of an agreement or official proof that someone owns land or a building
an intentional act, esp. a very bad or very good one:
examples: Whatever his motives, the deed did save a hundred thousand lives.

meanings.definition: a legal document that is an official record and proof of ownership of property:
examples: According to the deed, she owns the land from here to the river.

meanings.definition: a legal document that is an official record of an agreement or official proof that someone owns land or a building:
examples: Solicitors should ensure that borrowers understand the mortgage on offer before signing the mortgage deed.

meanings.definition: a metal box that can be locked, in which important documents are kept
in the UK, a written legal agreement made between a person or organization that owes money and the people or organizations that they owe money to. The agreement states how the debts are to be paid:
examples: Entering into a deed of arrangement is a way of avoiding bankruptcy.

meanings.definition: a legal agreement to give an asset or to sell a debt to someone else:
examples: This deed of assignment enables ownership of a life-insurance policy to be transferred from the current owner to another person or organization.
If the debt has been sold by the original creditor, there should be a deed of assignment stating who is now the legal owner of the debt.

meanings.definition: a legal agreement by which the people who are owed money agree to accept a part of the sum that they are owed. This is a type of deed of arrangement.
a legal document showing that the owner of a piece of land, a property, etc. has changed:
examples: The title of the property passes by means of a deed of conveyance carried out by a notary.

meanings.definition: in the UK, a legal document in which a person or organization promises to pay a certain sum of money regularly to another person or organization over a fixed period of time:
examples: And if you give to charity, use a deed of covenant or Gift Aid so that your favourite cause can claim the tax back.

meanings.definition: a legal agreement to give land or property to someone without charging them any money:
examples: My parents want to pass their house onto me as a deed of gift.

meanings.definition: a legal agreement in which a business and its creditors (= people it owes money to) choose another person or company to manage the business, so that the money owed can be paid back. This is a type of deed of arrangement:
examples: A deed of inspectorship was entered into, for the purpose of carrying on or winding up the business.

meanings.definition: a legal agreement to form a partnership (= a company owned by two or more people):
examples: The proposed merger was supposed to go live at the start of the year, but apparently, neither firm has signed a deed of partnership that would formalize the arrangement.

meanings.definition: a legal document that shows that the owner of property or shares has changed:
examples: Clive picked up the keys and the deed of transfer from a solicitor, and headed for the boatyard where our new acquisition lay.

meanings.definition: a legal agreement in which someone borrowing money allows another person called a trustee to be the owner of their property or assets until they pay back the loan. If the money is not paid back, the trustee can sell the property:
examples: The corporation had loaned him $1 million through a second deed of trust on the property.

meanings.definition: a legal document that creates a trust (= an organization which controls property or money for another person):
examples: We bought it through a deed of trust, in which my mother has 60 shares, and the four of us have 10 each.

meanings.definition: in the UK, a type of legal document, especially one that allows someone to officially change their name:
examples: He changed his name by deed poll.

meanings.definition: to consider or judge:

meanings.definition: going or being a long way down from the top or surface, or being of a particular distance from the top to the bottom:
examples: a deep well/mine
a deep river/sea
a deep cut
The hole is so deep you can't see the bottom.
The water's not deep here - look, I can touch the bottom.
Drill 20 holes, each 2 inches deep.
Take a few deep breaths (= breaths that fill the lungs with air) and calm down.

meanings.definition: having a large distance from one edge to the other, or having a particular distance from one edge to the other, especially the front and back edges:
examples: Is the alcove deep enough for bookshelves?
The wardrobe is 2 m high, 1 m wide and 60 cm deep.
By midnight, there were customers standing six deep (= in six rows) at the bar.

meanings.definition: very strongly felt or experienced and usually lasting a long time:
examples: Their son has been a deep disappointment to them.
We're in deep trouble.
She fell into a deep sleep.

meanings.definition: (of a sound) low:
examples: a wonderfully deep voice

meanings.definition: showing or needing serious thought, or not easy to understand:
examples: His films are generally too deep for me.

meanings.definition: In sports such as cricket and baseball, deep positions are far from where the batter is:
examples: The ball sailed towards the boundary in the direction of deep square leg.
The South African captain positioned deep fielders on each side of the ground.
The fielder caught the fly in deep right field.

meanings.definition: (of a colour) strong and dark:
examples: The sky was deep blue.

meanings.definition: a long way from the top or surface:
examples: The submarine sailed deep under the ice cap.
He thrust his hands deep in his pockets.

meanings.definition: In sports such as football, rugby, orice hockey , staying closer than usual to your own team's goal:
examples: Some midfielders play deep, having a more defensive role, while others go forward.
Capper played deep, relishing the competition in midfield areas.
At 2–0 up, Cambridge played deep, inviting the opposition to attack.
The manager was yelling at the team that they were defending too deep.

meanings.definition: going or being a long way down from the top or surface, or being at a particular distance down from the top:
examples: She had a deep cut on her left arm.
During the flood, the water in the basement was knee-deep (= it would reach the knees of an average adult).

meanings.definition: having a (sometimes stated) distance from front to back:
examples: I want the bookcase shelves to be 12 inches deep.
The crowd along the parade route was six deep (= in six rows).

meanings.definition: strongly felt or experienced, or having a strong and lasting effect:
examples: Our deep love for each other will last forever.
He awoke from a deep sleep.
Joseph, deep in thought (= thinking so much that he is not aware of others), didn’t hear Erin enter the room.

meanings.definition: difficult to understand; complicated:
examples: His book on how the brain works is too deep for me.

meanings.definition: (of a sound) low:
examples: He was a large man with a deep voice.

meanings.definition: (of a color) strong and dark:
examples: The sky is a deep blue.

meanings.definition: very large or serious:
examples: Employees were forced to accept deep cuts in pay and benefits.
a deep recession.
These deep discounts will be a major factor in stimulating local telephone competition in Pennsylvania.

meanings.definition: a very complete cleaning process that includes all parts of something, not just surfaces or places where dirt can be seen:
examples: After an infection we don't reopen a ward until it has been given a deep clean.
All parts of the baby seat are removable for deep cleans.

meanings.definition: to clean something in a very complete way that includes all its parts, not just its surfaces or places where dirt can be seen:
examples: 1500 hospitals were ordered by the government to be deep cleaned.
The carpet sweeper is OK but it doesn't really deep-clean.

meanings.definition: a large or greater than usual reduction in price:
examples: Some companies are offering deep discounts to attract shoppers.
The book is now being sold for $17.99, a deep discount from the $34.99 suggested list price.
The bonds are zero-coupon securities, which are sold at a deep discount compared to face value.

meanings.definition: a person or company that buys and sells shares, currency, and other investment products at a much reduced price:
examples: Generally speaking, deep discounters are simply the firms that charge the lowest commissions.

meanings.definition: a store that sells goods at prices that are very low compared to those in other stores:
examples: German deep discounters such as Aldi and Lidl have made a significant impact on the British High Street.

meanings.definition: a detailed examination of a subject:
examples: Walker's art takes a deep dive into issues around slavery and liberation.

meanings.definition: felt strongly and often hidden from other people:
examples: a deep-down certainty

meanings.definition: hot oil or fat that is deep enough to cover the food that is being cooked in it:
examples: The doughnuts are formed into rings and fried in deep fat.
If you do it properly, deep fat frying can actually be healthy.

meanings.definition: an electric machine for cooking food in enough hot oil or fat to cover it:
examples: Heat about 3 inches of oil in a deep fat fryer.
You can make these classic chips at home, without a deep-fat fryer.

meanings.definition: a container or a small room, operated by electricity, that stores food at a very cold temperature so that it becomes solid and can be kept safely for a long time:
examples: The seeds were stored in a deep freeze until needed.
He took some food from the deep-freeze and prepared lunch.
Steaks, roasts, and ribs can be kept in a deep freezer for 9 to 12 months.

meanings.definition: the state of being frozen, or seeming to be frozen:
examples: Doctors left the rest of the samples in deep freeze.
The relationship between the two countries was in deep-freeze.

meanings.definition: to store something by freezing it:
examples: The fruit keeps its flavour well if it is deep-frozen soon after picking.
Herbs can be deep frozen, dry or in ice cubes.

meanings.definition: thinking very hard:
examples: She sat, not listening, but deep in thought.

meanings.definition: near the middle of something, and a long distance from its edges:
examples: Little Red Riding Hood's grandmother lived in a house deep in the forest.
A scan showed damage to a small area located deep within the man's brain.
The waste was buried deep within the mountain.
Deep inside the cave you'll find ancient carvings.
These particles can lodge deep inside the lungs.

meanings.definition: a complete way of learning something that means you fully understand it and will not forget it:
examples: Deep learning is the kind you take with you through the rest of your life.

meanings.definition: a type of machine learning (= the process of computers improving their own ability to perform tasks by analysing new data) that uses many layers of data processing:
examples: Deep learning has been responsible for the most exciting developments in data science in recent years.

meanings.definition: the use of hyperlinks that connect you to a specific piece of information or content, rather than to the home page of a website:
examples: Search companies have argued that deep linking does not abuse copyright since they do not themselves host any pirated music.

meanings.definition: If an organization or person has deep pockets, they have a lot of money:
examples: Anyone who tries to save that company will need deep pockets.

meanings.definition: organizations such as military, police, or political groups that are said to work secretly in order to protect particular interests and to rule a country without being elected:
examples: The idea that there is a deep state governing behind the scenes is dismissed by some as a conspiracy theory.

meanings.definition: an area of business or research that involves using advanced science and technology, such as artificial intelligence, blockchain, or advances in biotechnology, to provide solutions to complicated problems:
examples: Deep tech, or deep technology, refers to companies, typically startups, whose business model is based on high tech innovation or significant scientific advances.
Deep tech has been referred to as the fourth wave of innovation after the industrial revolution, the information revolution, and the digital revolution.
We have the latest news and analysis on Europe's deeptech startups.

meanings.definition: a type of massage in which the person giving the massage presses hard on areas of the body where the muscles are very stiff or painful
a serious medical condition in which a blood clot (= a sticky mass of blood) forms in the veins of the legs or lungs
a bond which is sold at a much reduced price:
examples: Deep-discount bonds usually sell at a discount of at least 20% on their face value.

meanings.definition: prepared, cooked, or served in a deep dish:

meanings.definition: strongly felt or believed and very difficult to change or get rid of:

meanings.definition: to make someone or something less harmful, so that they are no longer dangerous:

meanings.definition: to remove the fat (= a solid or liquid substance from animals or plants that is usually white or yellow) from something, especially food containing meat:

meanings.definition: to fail to do something, such as pay a debt, that you legally have to do:
examples: People who default on their mortgage repayments may have their home repossessed.

meanings.definition: In sport, if a team or player defaults, they allow the other side to win without playing or completing a game:
examples: He moved into the next round after his opponent defaulted because of injury.

meanings.definition: the thing that exists or happens if you do not change it intentionally by performing an action:
examples: Unless something else is agreed, the default is to meet at the hotel at 7.00 p.m.

meanings.definition: a failure to do something, such as pay a debt, that you legally have to do:
examples: Defaults on loan repayments have reached 52,000 a month.
Any default on your mortgage payments may mean you will lose your house.

The national student loan default rate (= the number of people failing to pay) is estimated at one in ten.

meanings.definition: to fail to do something, such as pay a debt, that you legally have to do:
examples: The company defaulted on a $133 million loan.

meanings.definition: a failure to do something that you legally have to do, such as pay a debt:
examples: Defaults rose to 4 percent of all the bank’s loans.

meanings.definition: In sports, to win or lose by default is to win or lose because one side did not compete:

meanings.definition: a standard setting esp. of computer software, such as of type size or style:
examples: The default color of text on the screen is black.

meanings.definition: the fact of not paying interest or other money that is owed on time:

meanings.definition: the fact of not keeping to an agreement or contract:

meanings.definition: the way that something will happen or appear automatically, especially on a computer, if you do not make any different choices:

meanings.definition: to fail to pay interest or other money that is owed:

meanings.definition: something that provides protection against attack from enemies, or against something dangerous such as weather or an infection:

meanings.definition: the things said in court to prove that a person did not commit a crime:

meanings.definition: in some sports, the part of a team that tries to prevent the other team from scoring goals or points:

meanings.definition: protection against attack from enemies, or against something dangerous such as weather or an infection:
examples: The thin wooden walls provided little defence against the hurricane.

meanings.definition: to protect someone or something against attack or criticism:
examples: How can we defend our homeland if we don't have an army?

meanings.definition: to speak or write in support of someone or something:
examples: He vigorously defended his point of view.

meanings.definition: an investment that is very safe, with little or no risk, and whose value does not change very much over a period of time:

meanings.definition: the design of buildings or cities in a way that protects them against attack by an enemy:
examples: The north gate of the city is another impressive example of defensive architecture.

meanings.definition: the design of public spaces in a way that stops unwanted behaviour:
examples: Defensive architecture might include sloped window sills to stop people sitting on them, or benches with armrests positioned to stop people lying on them.

meanings.definition: a player in American football that plays on the defence, away from the line of scrimmage (= the line on which the ball is positioned at the beginning of each piece of action), and tries to stop the other team's receivers from catching the ball:
examples: He is one of the league's top defensive backs, with more interceptions than any other player over the last two seasons.
The team's strong corps of defensive backs has frustrated opposing quarterbacks all season.

meanings.definition: the players on the defence on an American football team who stand behind the line of scrimmage (= the line on which the ball is positioned at the beginning of each piece of action):
examples: The cornerbacks and safeties combine to form one of the strongest defensive backfields in the league.
The quarterback exploited the other team's lack of depth in the defensive backfield and was able to complete several long passes.

meanings.definition: the area on an American football field behind the defence's line of scrimmage (= the line on which the ball is positioned at the beginning of each piece of action):
examples: The play was nullified because there was an illegal hold in the defensive backfield.

meanings.definition: a player on the defence of an American football team who stands at the end of the line of scrimmage (= the line where the ball is positioned at the beginning of each piece of action):
examples: The defensive end tried to tackle the running back before he could gain enough for a first down.
The job of the defensive end is to try to contain the runner with the ball from going around the defence.

meanings.definition: in football and rugby, the half of the field in which your team's goal is:
examples: He touched the ball 12 times, all but one of those in the defensive half.
The team were particularly good at moving the ball forward quickly when they gained possession in their defensive half.

meanings.definition: the practice of giving medical tests or treatment that may not be necessary, in order to protect a doctor from possible future legal claims:
examples: Doctors practise more defensive medicine in hopes of avoiding lawsuits, which also drives up costs.
Defensive medicine practices creep into physicians' activities as early as medical school.

meanings.definition: a situation in which one company joins with a second company in order to avoid a third company taking control of it:
examples: The takeover bid has forced them into a defensive merger with their greatest competitor.

meanings.definition: in basketball, a rebound (= a ball that misses the goal and is able to be taken by any player) that is caught by the opposing team, rather than the one that attempted the shot:
examples: Defensive rebounds are important in helping a team win, because they limit an opponent to one shot.
He gets a lot of defensive rebounds because he is good at reading how the ball will bounce off the rim.

meanings.definition: a player on the defence of an American football team who stands near the middle of the line of scrimmage (= the line where the ball is positioned at the beginning of each piece of action):
examples: In a 4–3 defence, two defensive tackles line up at the line of scrimmage between two defensive ends.
The right defensive tackle was able to break through the offensive line and bring down the quarterback for a sack.

meanings.definition: in a way that protects someone or something against attack or injury:
examples: His fists were raised defensively when he spun and spotted the young man opposite.
People have long believed that plants respond to insect attacks defensively.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows you feel you are being criticized and do not like it:
examples: "It's not something I could have prevented," he said, a bit defensively.

meanings.definition: in a way that is intended to prevent the opposing player or players from scoring points, goals, etc.:
examples: He was always returning the ball defensively.
You're not going to beat Australia by batting defensively.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to the part of the team that tries to prevent the other team from scoring:
examples: Although we're quite dangerous in attack we are bad defensively.
France illustrated how vulnerable Ireland can be defensively.

meanings.definition: acting in a way that shows feelings of being criticized and the need to quickly explain :
examples: When asked where she went, she answered defensively.

meanings.definition: speech or behaviour in which someone is very eager to avoid being criticized:
examples: "I am assertive," she says, with only a trace of defensiveness.
He felt a surge of defensiveness, a need to deny or explain.

meanings.definition: to delay something until a later time:
examples: My bank has agreed to defer the repayments on my loan.
Can we defer making a decision until next week?

meanings.definition: to delay something until a later time; to postpone:
examples: You can order the furniture now and defer payment until September.

meanings.definition: to delay something until a later time:
examples: The committee decided to defer a decision on the takeover bid until a later date.
defer tax/payment
The scheme enables investors to defer paying taxes on the gain.

meanings.definition: to allow someone to make decisions or tell you what to do, or to accept their opinion or instructions, because of your respect for them or because of their higher rank, authority, knowledge, etc.:
examples: I have to defer to my boss on important decisions.
I defer to your judgment.

meanings.definition: to let another person decide, or to accept another person’s opinion, usually because you respect the knowledge or experience of that person:
examples: I deferred to Brian on the question of what to serve at the party.

meanings.definition: to allow another person or organization to make decisions for you because you respect them, or because of their higher rank, greater knowledge, etc.:
examples: For this type of decision, I usually defer to my boss.
In the last few years, the authority mostly has deferred to private developers to handle warehousing and distribution projects, because this is not the area of their expertise.

meanings.definition: respect and politeness:
examples: He treats her with such deference.
She covered her head in deference to (= because of a polite respect for) Muslim custom.

meanings.definition: respect shown for another person esp. because of that person’s experience, knowledge, age, or power:
examples: In deference to nature lovers, the town refused to grant a permit to builders who would have filled in a swamp used by many birds.

meanings.definition: a Latin word meaning "carrying away from a particular point", used in medical names and descriptions
polite and showing respect:
examples: She is always extremely deferential towards anyone in authority.

meanings.definition: in a way that is polite and shows a lot of respect:
examples: They bowed deferentially as she came into the room.
The shop assistant spoke deferentially to me.

meanings.definition: the act of delaying something until a later time, or an occasion when something is delayed until a later time:
examples: He did not seek deferment from military service.
I was granted a deferment on my education loans.

meanings.definition: (a) temporary delay in taking someone into the military forces:
examples: They got draft deferments as graduate students.

meanings.definition: in the UK, an agreed period of time that a person who has health insurance must be ill before the insurance company begins making payments to them:
examples: Insurance policies will usually be slightly more expensive if there is a shorter deferment period before they start paying out.

meanings.definition: able to be delayed until a later time:
examples: Furniture is a deferrable item of spending and if people are struggling for money they will wait.
deferrable taxes

→

delayed until a later time:
examples: deferred bonuses/compensation/charges

meanings.definition: an annuity (= yearly payment) in which an insurance company does not begin making payments until an agreed date:
examples: Writing deferred annuities for scheme members who are still in their twenties and thirties is highly risky for insurers that have trouble finding assets to back them up.

meanings.definition: money that has been received by a business but has not yet been shown in the accounts as income, for example, payment in advance for goods that have not yet been provided:
examples: A grant aiding the purchase of a fixed asset can be treated either as a deduction from cost or as a deferred credit.

meanings.definition: money that is borrowed by a company or an organization that can be changed into shares at a future date

→ 
        
         deferred credit
interest on a loan, bond, etc. that does not have to be paid until a future date:
examples: The bonds are sold at a discount to reflect the deferred interest payments.

meanings.definition: an amount included in a company's accounts for money that it owes, but that it will only pay back at a future date:
examples: At the end of the life of the lease, the deferred liability will be zero.

meanings.definition: a type of share where the dividend (= part of a company's profits) does not have to be paid until payments have been made on all other shares:
examples: The directors receive their cash compensation in deferred share units, an instrument designed to mirror the increases and declines of a company's stock.

meanings.definition: a type of share where the dividend (= part of a company's profits) does not have to be paid until a future date:
examples: The National Association of Pension Funds objects to the fact that the deferred shares are paid out regardless of the performance of the company over the intervening three years.

meanings.definition: money that a company owes in tax on income already earned, but that it will not pay until a future date:
examples: The poor performance was blamed on a deferred tax expense of $5.8 million and an abnormal loss of $7.9 million.
Provision must be made in the accounts for deferred taxation.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         defer

informal for

examples: I've got the flu. Deffo. No question.

meanings.definition: behaviour in which you refuse to obey someone or something:
examples: The demonstration is a pointless act of defiance against the government.
In defiance of the ceasefire, rebel troops are again firing on the capital.

meanings.definition: proud and determined opposition against authority or against someone more powerful than you are:
examples: They are continuing to publish their newspaper, in defiance of government attempts to close it down.

meanings.definition: proudly refusing to obey authority:
examples: a defiant attitude/gesture
The protesters blocking the entrance to the offices remained defiant this morning.

meanings.definition: not willing to accept criticism or disapproval:
examples: The CEO was in a defiant mood as she entered the boardroom.

meanings.definition: in a way that proudly refuses to obey authority:
examples: A group of prisoners stood on the roof, defiantly waving banners.
They defiantly refused to identify themselves in court.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows you are not willing to accept criticism or disapproval:
examples: He defiantly denies having done anything wrong.
She defiantly declared her innocence and claimed that prosecutors are trying to destroy her.

meanings.definition: the use of an electric current to stop any irregular and dangerous activity in the heart's muscles
a machine that uses an electric current to make someone's heart beat (= move) in a normal, regular way when it has stopped doing this, or to start a heart beating again when it has stopped:
examples: The paramedic had to use a defibrillator to shock the woman's heart into restarting.
We have installed portable defibrillators in public buildings.

meanings.definition: the state of not having, or not having enough, of something that is needed:
examples: Pregnant women often suffer from iron deficiency.
The blood tests revealed a deficiency in certain key minerals and vitamins.

meanings.definition: the state of not being good enough, or a fault that makes something not good enough:
examples: As the game went on, the team's deficiency was obvious.
Deficiencies in the education system have been much in the news.

meanings.definition: the lack of something that is needed in order to meet a particular standard or level of quality, or the thing that is lacking:
examples: Many women suffer from iron deficiency.

meanings.definition: a situation in which something is not as good as it should be:
examples: The audit revealed deficiences in the accounting system.
an operations/performance/service deficiency
We need to identify any deficiencies in the system and address them immediately.
address/correct/remedy a deficiency

meanings.definition: the amount by which something such as income or profit is less than it should be:
examples: They are not permitted to borrow additional funds as long as any deficiency exists in the capital reserve fund.
The accounts show a balance sheet deficiency - the amount by which liabilities exceed assets - of £13.19m at December 31.
The company has suffered recurring losses from operations and has a net capital deficiency that raises substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern.

meanings.definition: the amount by which the tax recorded in someone's financial records is less than the tax they actually owe, or a situation in which this happens:
examples: The IRS notified him that he was subject to a $10000 tax deficiency for the 2009 tax year.

meanings.definition: a disease caused by not eating enough of particular types of food that are necessary for good health:
examples: deficiency diseases, for example scurvy

meanings.definition: a state of not having, or not having enough of, something that is needed:
examples: The disease is caused by deficiency in vitamin D.
The blood tests revealed a deficiency in certain key minerals and vitamins.

meanings.definition: the quality in something of not being good enough, or a fault with something that makes it not good enough:
examples: The pandemic highlighted deficiencies in the country's health care system.
Deficiency in basic skills among school leavers is a serious problem.

meanings.definition: a judgment in a court of law that says that someone who has borrowed money must pay back what is still owed, after the property that was the security for the loan has been sold and was worth less than the amount that was borrowed:
examples: Being sued for a deficiency judgment after foreclosure seems to be one of the greatest worries of homeowners in danger of losing their homes.

meanings.definition: an official document saying that the amount of tax recorded in someone's financial records is less than the tax they actually owe:
examples: The court trimmed the total of his untaxed fraudulent income to $31,500 from the $53,000 listed by the IRS in its deficiency notice.

meanings.definition: not having enough of:
examples: A diet deficient in vitamin D may cause the disease rickets.

meanings.definition: not good enough:
examples: His theory is deficient in several respects.

meanings.definition: lacking or not good enough:
examples: A diet that is deficient in protein is harmful to children.

meanings.definition: not having enough of something:
examples: The study found evidence that these kinds of diets were deficient in certain important vitamins.
He seems to be deficient in basic social skills.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not good enough:
examples: The review failed to show that the attorney had performed deficiently.
The system was deficiently designed and implemented.

meanings.definition: the total amount by which money spent is more than money received, or the state of having spent more money than has been received:
examples: The presidential candidate claims that he can cut the deficit in half within five years.
With a budget deficit of nearly £26 billion, the state plans to slash spending on schools and police.
The country is running a balance-of-payments deficit of $250 million.
The UK's deficit in manufactured goods fell slightly in the last three months.
What happened to cause this lurch from surplus to deficit?
A third of schools in the county say they are in deficit.

meanings.definition: the amount by which a team or player is behind in a game or competition:
examples: They overcame a two-goal deficit to draw even in the second half.
It was the first time in baseball history a team had overcome a three-games-to-none deficit in the World Series.

meanings.definition: a temporary or permanent lack in someone's ability to operate normally:
examples: Children neglected in early life are likely to exhibit deficits in psychosocial functioning.
The disease results in increasing levels of cognitive deficit.
Air pollution has been associated with lung function deficits in children.

meanings.definition: the amount by which money spent is more than money received:
examples: The theater has been operating at a deficit of over $150,000 a year.

meanings.definition: the total amount by which money spent by a business or government is more than the money it receives:
examples: The two companies between them have reported a deficit of nearly $14bn.
About a third of the nation's non-profit arts presenters run a large deficit each year, according to Charity Navigator.
reduce/cut a deficit
federal/government/public deficit
The US balance of payments deficit was running at over 4% of gross domestic product.

meanings.definition: the amount by which something, especially an amount of money, is smaller than it should be:
examples: a pension/pension fund deficit
The company reported that an estimated $31.5 million deficit in this year's operating budget would end up at about $20 million as a result of savings.
There is a deficit of trust between the customer and the banks, which yesterday's headline figure will do little to dispel.

meanings.definition: the practice of a government borrowing extra money that it needs because it is spending more than it receives from taxes, etc.:
examples: Looming behind the current concern is the huge overhang of Japanese government debt, resulting from a decade of deficit financing.

meanings.definition: a situation in which money spent is more than money received for a particular type of activity, or the amount of money involved:
examples: The deficit in the state budget has now reached $20 million.
Employers proposed a wage freeze to offset a deficit in the pension fund.

meanings.definition: a permanent or temporary lack of a particular ability:
examples: Children neglected in early life are likely to exhibit deficits in psychosocial functioning.
Problems caused by drugs include addiction, overdose, disease, and temporary deficits in skills needed to operate machinery (for example, to drive a car).

meanings.definition: the process of reducing the amount by which a government's spending is more than the money it receives in taxes, etc.:
examples: a deficit reduction package/plan/target
The IMF believes that the short-term pain of deficit reduction will be rewarded with long-term gain as interest rates fall and resources are freed up for use by the more efficient private sector.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a government's spending is greater than the money it receives in taxes, etc.:
examples: Growing foreign debt and deficit spending have brought South America's second-largest economy to a standstill.

meanings.definition: past simple and past participle of defy
to spoil something or someone so that that thing or person is less beautiful or pure:
examples: It's a shame that such a beautiful area has been defiled by a rubbish dump.
The soldiers deliberately defiled all the holy places.

meanings.definition: If something is definable, you can explain and describe its meaning and exact limits:
examples: definable rules of grammar/syntax
Your office must be a clearly definable space in which no personal activities take place.

meanings.definition: If a word or phrase is definable, you can say what the meaning of it is:
examples: For every definable term in international law there are clear cases and more complicated cases.
The Book Talker has eight hundred and forty-six definable phrases.

meanings.definition: in a way that can be clearly explained and described:
examples: His definably northern singing voice is part of a long tradition.
Without saying anything definably humorous, they always manage to raise a laugh.

meanings.definition: to say what the meaning of something, especially a word, is:
examples: In the dictionary, "reality" is defined as "the state of things as they are, rather than as they are imagined to be".
Before I answer your question, could you define your terms a little more (= explain what you mean by the words you have used)?

meanings.definition: to explain and describe the meaning and exact limits of something:
examples: Your rights and responsibilities are defined in the citizens' charter.
Your role in the project will be strictly defined (= limited to particular areas).
I'd hate to feel that I was defined by (= that my life got its meaning and importance only from) my job.

meanings.definition: to show clearly the edge or shape of something:
examples: The outline of the castle on the hill was clearly defined against the evening sky.
I use a lip pencil to define my lips before applying lipstick.
A low wall defines the site.

meanings.definition: to describe the meaning of something, esp. a word, or to explain something more clearly so that it can be understood:
examples: How would you define “jaded”?

meanings.definition: to show clearly the edge or shape of something:
examples: The dark figures are sharply defined on the white background.

meanings.definition: to say what the meaning of something, especially a word, is:
examples: Economists normally define a recession as two successive quarters of negative growth.

meanings.definition: to explain and state the meaning and exact limits of something:
examples: a defined goal/objective
If you want employees to be more productive, then you must define and measure productivity precisely.

meanings.definition: to believe that a particular quality or fact is enough to tell you what a person or thing is like, especially when this is not fair or true :
examples: She refused to be defined by her difficult upbringing.
You can't define people by the type of music they listen to.
His whole life was defined by football - playing it, watching it, and writing about it.

meanings.definition: to say what the meaning of something, especially a word, is:
examples: Samuel Johnson famously defined a lexicographer as a "harmless drudge".
The military defines a conscientious objector as someone who is against military service because of their philosophical, religious, or moral beliefs.

meanings.definition: used to describe a pension arrangement in which the value of the pension is fixed, and usually decided by the length of time you worked for a company and the salary that you earned:
examples: a defined-benefit pension/plan/scheme

meanings.definition: used to describe a pension arrangement in which the amount paid into the pension plan is fixed but the value of the pension that is received may change, according to how the money in the plan was invested:
examples: a defined-contribution pension/plan/scheme

meanings.definition: very important in understanding or describing something:
examples: The attacks were the defining event of his presidency.
Electronic dance music is characterized by several defining features.
There are many differences between the candidates, but none is more defining than this issue.

meanings.definition: (of a clause) giving information about someone or something that is necessary in order to understand who or what is being referred to, or (of a pronoun) used in a clause like this:
examples: No commas are used before defining clauses.
In "They interviewed the woman whose dog had been rescued", "whose dog had been rescued" is a defining relative clause because it makes clear which woman is being talked about.
We can use "who" or "that" as a defining relative pronoun to talk about people.

meanings.definition: a thing or quality that is a very important part of how something is remembered, understood, or described:
examples: The Shard has already become one of the defining features of the London skyline.
Electronic dance music is characterized by several defining features.

meanings.definition: a very important point in a period of time or a very important event, that people will remember as having changed a situation in an important way:
examples: The end of the Cold War was a defining moment for the world in more ways than one.
In years to come, people will look back on this as a defining moment in the country's history.
The exhibition featured photographs of some of the defining moments in her career.

meanings.definition: the set of words that has been used to write all the definitions in a particular dictionary
fixed, certain, or clear:
examples: The date for the meeting is now definite: 5 March .
She has very definite opinions.
We need a definite answer by tomorrow.
"Are you sure I'm invited too?" "Yes, Dan was very definite about it on the phone."
There's been a definite improvement in your English since you came here.

meanings.definition: something that is certain to happen:
examples: Let's make the 9th a definite - we'll have dinner and then go to the movies.
She's a definite for the Olympic team.

meanings.definition: fixed, certain, or clear:
examples: We haven’t picked a definite date, but it will probably be in June.

meanings.definition: the grammatical name for the word "the" in English, or the words in other languages that have a similar use
the word “the” in English, or the words in other languages that have a similar use
something that you think you might do, but are not certain about:
examples: "Are you going to Helen's party?" "It's a definite maybe."

meanings.definition: without any doubt:
examples: Have you definitely decided to go to Costa Rica?
He definitely said he'd be here.
"Are you going to have children?" "Oh, definitely (= without any doubt)."
"She's not coming?" "No, definitely not."

meanings.definition: without any doubt; certainly:
examples: I don’t like that place – I’m definitely not going back there.
"Are you really going to quit your job?" "Definitely!"

meanings.definition: a statement that explains the meaning of a word or phrase:
examples: a dictionary definition
What is the definition of "mood"?

meanings.definition: a description of the features and limits of something:
examples: The legal definition of what is and what is not pornography is very unsatisfactory.

meanings.definition: how clear an image or sound is:
examples: The photograph lacks definition.

meanings.definition: a statement that explains the meaning of a word or phrase:
examples: What is the definition of “mood”?

meanings.definition: the degree to which something can be clearly seen or heard:
examples: The tape recorded conversation lacked definition – there was too much background noise.

meanings.definition: not able to be changed or improved:
examples: a definitive judgment/ruling
There are no definitive answers to this problem.
The police have no definitive proof of her guilt.

meanings.definition: considered to be the best of its type:
examples: He's written the definitive guide to Thailand.

meanings.definition: firm, final, and complete; not to be questioned or changed:
examples: There is no definitive scientific evidence that coffee is harmful.

meanings.definition: a clear decision or solution that cannot be or does not need to be changed:
examples: There are no definitive answers to this problem.
We do not know whether the mass is malignant, but further tests should provide a definitive answer.

meanings.definition: a fact or piece of information that shows something is true in a way that cannot be doubted:
examples: The police have put together a profile of the suspect but do not yet have definitive proof of his identity.
The secret service never produced definitive proof that the attack was organized by that group.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not able to be changed or improved:
examples: The President has spoken definitively about the situation in the region.
The link between lung cancer and air pollution has not been definitively proved.

meanings.definition: If something that has air or gas inside it deflates, or is deflated, it becomes smaller because it loses the air or gas:
examples: to deflate a balloon/tyre

meanings.definition: to cause something to become weaker:
examples: The party's ambitions have been deflated by the two recent by-election defeats.

meanings.definition: to make someone lose confidence or feel less important:
examples: They were totally deflated by losing the game.

meanings.definition: to reduce the supply of money in an economy
to allow air or gas to escape from within a container:
examples: When the roads are icy, you may have to deflate your tires a bit.

meanings.definition: fig. Someone or something that is deflated suddenly feels or is considered less important:
examples: The allegations deflate the respect people have for the presidency.

meanings.definition: when an economy deflates or is deflated, prices fall and there is a reduction in wages and government spending, and low levels of growth:
examples: The chancellor will have to keep rates high and deflate the economy to keep the lid on prices and finance the trade deficit.
The fear is that economies fueled by aid dollars will deflate after international agencies leave.

meanings.definition: to reduce the value or price of something, or to become less valuable or expensive:
examples: Some people are angry, arguing that the state has artificially deflated housing values in the area.
Over the past ten years, telecom prices have deflated by 50% while levels of competition have never been more intense.

meanings.definition: feeling less confident and positive than before:
examples: Her criticism left me feeling a bit deflated.

meanings.definition: the situation in which something becomes weaker, or something or someone becomes less confident than before:
examples: a feeling of deflation after the party

meanings.definition: a reduction of the supply of money in an economy, and therefore a reduction of economic activity, that is often part of an intentional government plan to reduce prices
a reduction in value:
examples: There has been a deflation in property values.

meanings.definition: an economic situation in which prices fall and there is a reduction in wages and government spending, and low levels of growth:
examples: Global deflation is squeezing profits and extinguishing jobs.
He warned that Euroland could sink into deflation unless the central bankers tailored their policies to promote economic growth.
In monetary deflation, a contracting money supply causes prices and demand to decline.

meanings.definition: a situation in which the value or price of something is reduced:
examples: The current deflation of home prices is having a profound effect on American society.

asset deflation.

meanings.definition: connected with a reduction of the supply of money in an economy, and therefore a reduction of economic activity, that is often part of an intentional government plan to reduce prices:
examples: a deflationary budget/policy

meanings.definition: causing deflation:
examples: Unemployment is the unfortunate legacy of two decades of deflationary economic policies.

meanings.definition: a figure that is used to change current prices or wages so that they can be compared to past prices or wages, by removing the effect of inflation:
examples: The GDP deflator - the overall inflation measure covering all price changes in the economy and not just at the consumer level - rose 0.4 percent in the third quarter to 128.
The price deflator measures the magnitude of price increases and detects whether higher costs drive consumers away from a product.

meanings.definition: to change direction after hitting something, or to cause something to do this :
examples: The ball deflected off my shoulder, straight into the goal.

If a huge meteor was heading towards us, our best hope could be to deflect it away from the Earth using a nuclear explosion.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to change from or stop what they were intending to do:
examples: His initial defeats did not deflect him from his ambitions.
She listens to him, but doesn't allow herself to be deflected from her purpose.

meanings.definition: to avoid something such as criticism, blame, or a question being directed at you:
examples: The president deflected criticism of his economic record by focusing on crime.

meanings.definition: to attack or blame another person rather than accepting criticism or blame for your own actions:
examples: When someone deflects, they are trying to feel less guilty, avoid negative consequences, and put the blame on others.

meanings.definition: to cause something to change direction, or to suddenly go in a different direction:
examples: The ionosphere deflects radio waves.
fig. The mayor deflected (= did not answer directly) questions about his political plans.

meanings.definition: to avoid blame being directed at you:

meanings.definition: to avoid criticism being directed at you:

examples: Most of the town was demolished by the tornado.

examples: She works like a demon.

examples: That's the last time I take care of her kids - I'll be glad when the little demons go home.

meanings.definition: a negative feeling that causes you to worry or behave badly:
examples: She had her demons and, later in life, they drove her to drink.

meanings.definition: an evil spirit
to officially stop using particular notes or coins, or a particular currency:
examples: In 2002 the currencies of twelve European countries were demonetized and replaced with the Euro.

meanings.definition: wild and evil:

meanings.definition: in a wild and evil way, like a devil (= evil spirit):

meanings.definition: wild and evil:

meanings.definition: in a wild and evil way, like a devil (= evil spirit):

meanings.definition: in a way that can be proved:
examples: That's demonstrably untrue!

meanings.definition: to show or make something clear:
examples: These numbers clearly demonstrate the size of the economic problem facing the country.

meanings.definition: to show something and explain how it works:
examples: He got a job demonstrating kitchen equipment in a department store.

meanings.definition: to express or show that you have a particular feeling, quality, or ability:

meanings.definition: to make a public expression that you are not satisfied about something, especially by marching or having a meeting:
examples: Thousands of people gathered to demonstrate against the new proposals.

meanings.definition: to show how to do something; explain:
examples: He demonstrated how to use the new software.

meanings.definition: to show that something is true; prove:

meanings.definition: an occasion when a group of people march or stand together to show that they disagree with or support something or someone:
examples: The students are holding a demonstration against the proposed changes.

meanings.definition: a way of expressing a feeling or a quality:
examples: Huge crowds followed the funeral procession in a public demonstration of grief.

meanings.definition: the act of showing someone how to do something or how something works:

examples: a demonstration of friendship

meanings.definition: an event in which a group of people march or stand together to show that they disagree with or support something or someone:
examples: Students staged a protest demonstration in the school gym.

meanings.definition: the act of showing someone how to use a product or how a new system or product works:
examples: an online sales demonstration

meanings.definition: if a business, system, etc. has a demonstration effect, others are influenced by it and try to copy it:
examples: Multinational hotel companies not only increased tourism on the island but also produced a strong demonstration effect among local establishments.

meanings.definition: one example of a system or product, used for showing people how it works or how they can use it:
examples: GameStop stores have demonstration models for customers to try out.

meanings.definition: a planned series of actions to show someone how to do something or how something works:
examples: Let me give you a demonstration of how the camera works.

meanings.definition: an event or action that shows a feeling or quality that someone has:
examples: Huge crowds followed the funeral procession in a public demonstration of grief.

meanings.definition: an event that shows that something is true or important:
examples: This disaster is a clear demonstration of the need for tighter controls.

meanings.definition: a form of a software product, usually given to people free so they can try using it, especially to encourage them to buy the original product:
examples: Click to download a free demonstration version of the game.
The demo version has the same features and functionality but does NOT permit file saves.

meanings.definition: If you are demonstrative, you show your feelings or behave in a way that shows your love:
examples: We're a very demonstrative family.

meanings.definition: Demonstrative words are words, for example "this", "that", "these", and "those", that show which person or thing is being referred to:
examples: In the sentence "This is my brother", "this" is a demonstrative pronoun.

meanings.definition: showing which person or thing is being referred to:
examples: a demonstrative adjective
In “This is my brother,” “this” is a demonstrative pronoun.

meanings.definition: behaving in a way that clearly shows your feelings:
examples: She was always a demonstrative child.

meanings.definition: an amount of money, shares, etc. from a particular bank account that someone leaves in their will (= a legal document in which they state what should be done with their money and property when they die). If the bank account no longer exists, payment is made from the dead person's estate (= all their money and property).
showing your feelings or behaving in a way that shows your love:
examples: Some cultures show affection for children more demonstratively than others.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows something or makes something clear:
examples: These claims are demonstratively false.

meanings.definition: the action of showing your feelings or behaving in a way that shows your love:
examples: He put out a hand with uncharacteristic demonstrativeness and touched her cheek.

meanings.definition: a person who explains how something works or how to do something:

meanings.definition: a person who marches or stands with a group of people to show that they disagree with or support something or someone:

meanings.definition: a word that is a name for someone who comes from a particular place:
examples: The demonym for Spain is a Spaniard, not "a Spanish".

meanings.definition: the process of making someone lose confidence, enthusiasm, and hope:
examples: Increasing state power was responsible for the demoralization of the workers.

meanings.definition: to make someone or something feel much less confident:
examples: Losing several games in a row had completely demoralized the team.

meanings.definition: to weaken the confidence of someone:
examples: The team was tired and thoroughly demoralized.

meanings.definition: having lost your confidence, enthusiasm, and hope:
examples: After the game, the players were tired and demoralized.

meanings.definition: making you lose confidence, enthusiasm, and hope:

meanings.definition: in a way that makes you lose confidence, enthusiasm, and hope:

meanings.definition: to lower someone or something in rank or position:
examples: The captain was demoted to sergeant for failing to fulfil his duties.

meanings.definition: to lower someone in rank or position:
examples: The department is planning to demote some managers as a cost-saving measure.

meanings.definition: to move someone to a less senior job than the one they had before:
examples: Her manager demoted her from her job as a supervisor.

meanings.definition: to move a company, team, etc. to a lower place in a list because it has performed badly:
examples: The company was demoted from the FTSE 1000 after its shares slumped 13p to 34p.

meanings.definition: to move someone to a lower rank or position:

meanings.definition: in or relating to a form of language used by ordinary people, that includes informal expressions and slang:
examples: He has made poetry out of demotic speech.

We are writing for a very diverse population, so our language must be more demotic.

meanings.definition: relating to or used, made, enjoyed, etc. by ordinary people:
examples: The demotic pieces of art enjoyed by the majority were dismissed as formally simplistic or sentimental.
Travelling by train in India is still a genuinely demotic experience.
His athletically hybrid style of dance was demotic but classy.

meanings.definition: describing or relating to a simple form of ancient Egyptian writing used from about 650 BCE to the 5th century CE, when it was replaced by Coptic, which uses a form of the Greek alphabet:
examples: Copies of the text of the decree have survived written in ancient Egyptian, in both hieroglyphic and demotic scripts.
Fragments of papyrus were found containing Demotic Egyptian text.

meanings.definition: describing or relating to the modern form of Greek that is used in ordinary speech and writing:
examples: As Education Minister, he formally established demotic Greek as the language of the land.
His work moves from the Hellenistic golden age through to today's Demotic Greek, the language of the people.

meanings.definition: a form of a language used by ordinary people, that includes informal expressions and slang:
examples: Unlike many politicians, he is not afraid of the colloquial and the demotic.

The language is an odd mixture of Victorian English and early 21st-century demotic.

meanings.definition: a simple form of ancient Egyptian writing used from about 650 BCE to the 5th century CE, when it was replaced by Coptic, which uses the Greek alphabet:
examples: Some of these letter forms derive from Demotic and others from Coptic.
